For information about Housing and the Residential Rent Stabilization Program please check our website at www.hayward-ca.gov/housing. Rent Review Kiosk: Hard copies of the Residential Rent Stabilization forms and materials are available for self-service on the first floor of City Hall. File a Petitions: Petition can be filed by mail, sent by email to housing@hayward-ca.gov, or dropped off at the Rent Review Kiosk drop box. File Notices: Rent increase notices and notices of termination of tenancy can be filed by mail, emailed to rentalnotifications@hayward-ca.gov or dropped off at the Rent Review Kiosk. Pay Rent Stabilization Fee: Rent Stabilization Fee can be paid by mail or online at https://haywardselfservice.us/hss/ Mailing Address: Housing Division 777 B Street, Fourth floor Hayward, Ca 94541 To view a list of departments with modified hours or services visit our website: www.hayward-ca.gov/covid-19. For your convenience, please see below for frequently asked questions and services.   COVID-19 Updates Make a Payment   Hayward Water Support   Pay a Traffic Ticket   Report an Abandoned Vehicle  Signup for AC Alert Subscribe to Public Safety emails   For all other questions or concerns, please utilize our Access Hayward system. Updated: 7-13-2020 9:58 am SMR. 

Provides a one-time rent relief grant directly to landlords on behalf of low-income tenants to reduce burden on tenants due to COVID. Helps offset corresponding lost revenue that landlords need to provide housing services. Ensure landlords receive the revenue needed to maintain housing services. Bay Area Community Services (BACS) will be administering the program on behalf of the City of Hayward.
application_process: Must complete online-application: https://housing.bayareacs.org/
required_documents:
Valid ID (any photo identification including name, date of birth, etc.)
Current lease agreement or documentation of rent paid
Documentation of income and income loss (such as paycheck stubs showing difference in amounts; application or screenshot to Unemployment Department; two bank statements showing difference, Layoff Letter, etc.)
Proof of housing crisis (such as documentation certifying tenant is behind on payments, unable to pay rent, etc.). If the tenant does not have this, they will need to certify/attest they have a bona fide housing crisis and/or do not have the ability to pay the next months’ rent.
W9 from Landlord / Property Owner (BACS can provide a copy of the form). Tenants must request a copy of the W-9 from their landlords. Landlords may submit to the tenants or to BACS directly.
eligibility:
Applicant must be:
o Very low-income tenants (up to 50% AMI) OR
o Low income (up to 80% AMI) with high rent burden (30% or higher).
• Have been unable to pay full rent because they experienced and can demonstrate hardship resulting from COVID-19 in one or more of the following ways (with flexibility regarding other experiences not listed):
o Loss of or reduction in employment or wages
o Increased medica

name: Eviction Moratorium County of Alameda
description:
On Tuesday March 24, 2020 the Alameda County ​Board of Supervisors unanimously ​passed an emergency ordinancesuspending evictions in the Unincorporated County for renters and homeowners ​who are experiencing loss of income, significant out-of-pocket medical expenses or childcare needs as a result of the County COVID-19 shelter mandate.  The Ordinance took effect immediately upon passage and will be in effect until April 23, 2020 ​unless extended by the Board. 
Unincorporated County residents who are served a Notice of Termination ​while the ordinance is in effect ​will need to provide documentation of loss of income, substantial medical expenses or child care impacts.
Violators are subject to a $1000 fine per violation and may be subject to civil proceedings. 
​The ordinance and associated staff report are available here.
application_process: Visit website for more information http://www.acgov.org/board/bos_calendar/documents/DocsAgendaReg_03_24_20/GENERAL%20ADMINISTRATION/Regular%20Calendar/CDA_293014.pdf
required_documents: No information has been provided by Agency
eligibility: Residents of the Unincorporated County for renters and homeowners ​who are experiencing loss of income, significant out-of-pocket medical expenses or childcare needs as a result of the County COVID-19 shelter mandate.

name: Eviction moratorium for residential renters, nonprofit organization renters, and small business renters of Oakland
description:
Note: On Tuesday, May 19, 2020, the Oakland City Council extended the eviction moratorium for residential renters, nonprofit organization renters, and small business renters (generally those with fewer than 100 employees) through August 31, 2020. Updated: 7-13-2020 9:07 a.m. SMR 

This moratorium will prohibit most evictions, effective immediately and continuing through August 31, 2020, unless the City Council extends that date. Additionally, the moratorium prohibits residential rent increases above 3.5% (the Consumer Price Index, or CPI) and prohibits any late fees related to COVID-19 issues in residential units. Unpaid rent will still be due, and the moratorium does not relieve tenants of the obligation to pay unpaid back rent in the future. The Ordinance also prohibits evictions based on nonpayment of rent that became due during the Local Emergency when the tenant suffered a substantial reduction of income or substantial increase of expenses due to COVID-19.
application_process: Visit the website to apply
required_documents: No information has been provided by Agency
eligibility: Oakland residential renters, nonprofit organization renters, and small business renters (generally those with fewer than 100 employees).
schedule: Online hours 24/7. No information has been provided by Agency for phone hours

name: Eviction Moratorium- Union City
description: The eviction moratorium will last until May 31, or until the expiration of local or state emergency declarations, whichever is later. It will protect any residential or commercial tenant from being evicted for not paying their rent “where the failure to pay rent is from income loss resulting from the coronavirus.
application_process: Tenants have 10 days after rent is due to notify landlord
required_documents: Any documents showing loss of income or any kind of medical documentation
eligibility: Renters in Union City will need to notify their landlords within 10 days after their next rent payment is due that they won’t be able to pay because of a coronavirus-related issue.

description: A number of temporary measures to protect tenants during the public health emergency have been enacted at state, county, and city levels.
application_process: Call to apply
required_documents:
Tell your landlord in writing as soon as possible, before rent is due. Keep copies of what you send and your landlord’s responses.
Take pictures of all documentation that shows you lost income because of COVID-19. These can include:
Paystubs
Notes from your boss
Bank statements
Notices that your kids’ school is closed
Doctor’s note showing that you had to stay home to care for yourself or someone else

name: Alameda County Workforce Development Board (ACWDB)
description:
COVID-19 Emergency Response Suppotive Services (CERSS)
Alameda County Workforce Development Board (ACWDB) has launched a new initiative to help some of our most vulnerable residents receive up to $800. Eligible participants can receive additional resources to help offset the cost of housing, transportation, utility bills, and technology to facilitate working from home.
 
These services are in addition to unemployment benefits and other safety net programs. ACWDB has four locations geographically disbursed throughout Alameda County. Interested individuals should contact their nearest Career Services Provider immediately as assistance is limited and available on a first-come, first-served basis.
Provides job seekers with access to tools, resources and services that assist them with obtaining their employment goals. These services are available throughout Alameda County through a Comprehensive One Stop Career Center (serving the Eden area in Hayward) and through workforce services networks that serve the Tri-Cities, North Cities, and Valley areas of Alameda County.

Offers RAPID RESPONSE services to Employers and Dislocated Workers when companies undergo downsizing, relocation, layoffs and closures. Provides information on: career planning, vocational retraining, and re-employment.
application_process: By phone or online for program information. No direct services offered at WDB's administrative offices.
required_documents: Verification of eligibility for federal programs.
eligibility: Residents of Alameda County excluding the City of Oakland or job seekers who have worked in Alameda County excluding Oakland during 6 months prior to application. The unemployed, underemployed, low income, or individuals with barriers to employment. Laid-off workers eligible for unemployment benefits.

For more information about services and programs, a weekly orientation is held every week (by appointment only). Services offered include job search workshops with instruction in job seeking, resume writing and interviewing skills. Offers weekly job clubs and networking opportunities, vocational, career and supportive counseling as well as classroom and on-the-job training. Resources include: job listings, library of career-related materials, job search videos, information on vocational schools and training, community resources, labor market, and employers. Access to the California Employment Development Department's (EDD's) CalJOBS program. Offers basic beginning computer assistance. Provides computer stations with word processing, database, spreadsheet, internet resumes and career resource software as well as fax machines, copiers and phones for employer contact. Also assists employers in finding employees by posting job opportunities.
application_process: Walk-in to register; bring photo ID and social security card; CalWORKs clients schedule an appointment.
eligibility: Legally authorized to work. Additional requirements may apply.

name: Youth Employment Opportunity Program (YEOP)
description:
Provides special services to youth age 15-25. Assists youth in achieving their educational and vocational goals. Services include:
  • peer advising
  • referrals to supportive services
  • workshops
  • job referrals
  • placement assistance
  • referrals to training and community outreach centers
application_process: Visit during program hours
required_documents: No information has been provided by Agency
eligibility: Youth, age 15-25 at risk of not achieving educational or occupational goal.

name: 90-Day Job Rehabilitation, Recovery and Fundraising Program
Academic Advising and Career Education Center (AACE)
description:
One-stop center for both academic advising and career development assistance, and career services. Counselors guide students in understanding and completing all General Education and graduation requirements in addition to helping them clarify and attain their career goals. Services include:
  • Career Education
  • Major Exploration
  • Academic Advising
  • Resources for employers, students with disabilities,etc.
application_process: Call for an appointment
required_documents: No information provided by Agency
eligibility: Students attending the University

name: ACBHCS Vocational Program
description:
Note: Due to many pharmacies being currently shuttered, and in case of the event of a prescribing emergency the pharmacy team and the Office of the Medical Director is available to assist in identifying alternate resources.  Please call 510-567-8106.

Note: Office is not open to the public. Call for more information. 
Posted 4-10-2020 3:19pm SMR

Provides Individual Placement and Support, Supported Employment to mental health consumers that have expressed an interest to work. Consumers are referred from Service Teams representing mental health clinics in Alameda County Behavioral Health Care Services (ACBHCS). Job Plans are based on the individual preferences of the consumer and include vocational counseling and outreach, competitive job search and retention, and ongoing collaboration with individuals team.
application_process: Must be referred by case manager, a Service Team or Level 1 Specialty provider. If not currently receiving these services can call ACCESS at 1-800-491-9099 to assess service needs.
required_documents: No Information has been provided by Agency.
eligibility: Must be a part of a mental health service team at Alameda County Behavioral Health Care Services and be at least 16 years old and able to express an interest and motivation to work.

name: Administration Office / Hayward Community Resource Center
America's Job Center of California AJCC - Fremont (FRC Building))
CalFresh Employment and Training Program (CalFresh E&T)
description:
Prepares Clients for possible employment through a variety of activities, including job club and job search. Employable General Assistance and/or CalFresh recipients are currently not required to participate in employment program for continued eligibility.
NOTE: Lobbies are Temporarily Closed to Help Prevent the Spread of COVID-19. The below Alameda County Social Services Agency office lobbies are currently closed. We will continue to provide essential services. Clients who are receiving or wish to apply for Medi-Cal, CalFresh, CalWORKs, Refugee Cash Assistance, and General Assistance may use available telephone, fax, mail, and online services. Applications, renewals, documents, and reports can be submitted for most programs online at www.MyBenefitsCalWIN.org. You may also submit information by fax at 510-670-5095 or by mail at P.O. Box 12941, Oakland, CA 94604.

During the temporary closure, limited in-person access will be available for the following:
  • Emergency Electronic Benefit Transfer (EBT) Card/ Benefits Identification Card (BIC) or check pick-up
  • Homeless mail pick-up
  • Cash Assistance Program for Immigrants (CAPI) Applications
  • Clients who do not have access to a telephone and need to comply with a required program interview
Applications will continue to be available at offices in designated areas for all benefit programs, and community members may complete, sign and return documents for processing using a secure drop box during regular business hours, 8:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Application Forms With Links

name: California State School for the Deaf Supportive Services
description:
Program provides:
  • infant education
  • preschool education
  • elementary education
  • secondary and high school education
  • career and technical education
Continuing and community education is provided through local schools and adult education programs. The school is also a residential program and a resource center providing information and referral for the northern California area. Students from nearby communities attend on a day school-basis.
application_process: Referrals through local school districts and parent application.
required_documents: No information has been provided by Agency
eligibility: Age birth to 21, must be diagnosed deaf or hard of hearing.

name: CalWORKs Program (LaneyWORKs)
description: Teaches, trains, counsels and helps CalWORKs students to facilitate transition from public assistance to employment and self-sufficiency. Provides case management, academic, career and personal counseling,  job readiness training and child care. Also offers referral assistance for financial aid, assistance with books and supplies, work-study and internships, and job search/placement assistance.
application_process: By phone, in person.
eligibility: Students on TANF or CalWORKs.

name: Career Advancement Programs; Pathways for Men and Women
description:
Note: Office is closed until shelter in place has been lifted. Still able to leave messages for staff. Posted: 4-16-2020 12:22pm SMR

Offers professional skills development, such as communication, goal-setting, and a network of support to help individuals create new opportunities for themselves, their families and their communities. Helps individuals work with each other and with top career coaches. They develop specific action plans for job retention and career advancement. PATHWAYS is a 6-session workshops designed to help participants learn what it takes to excel on the job. Includes conflict resolution, problem solving, teamwork and communication skills. Applications are accepted on a rolling basis. Workshops meet once a week for 2 hours, for 6 weeks.
application_process: By phone (EXT 213) to request an application. For Pathways program: Applications accepted on a rolling basis.
eligibility: Low-income men and women working, ready to determine next steps in career. Not appropriate for individuals in "active job search" mode.

name: Career Connect
description: Career Connect is a 7-week career exploration and preparation program for Oakland students Grades 6th-12th. Students will get a jump start on their career planning as they begin or continue to sharpen their skills through interactive learning activities. Exploration of career fields will broaden students’ knowledge while narrowing their career and college choices as they assess their skills, talents, and interests. Career and life skills will be built upon simultaneously.
application_process: Call for information
eligibility: Oakland tudents in grades 6-12

name: Champion Workforce (Employment)
description:
Note: Closed until further notice. Posted 4-10-2020 2:10pm SMR 

Assists homeless and extremely low-income adults to enter the workforce. The program is designed to systematically help participants address barriers to obtaining employment and receive training in key areas to develop workforce skills. After undergoing training, men and women are placed in temporary labor positions in painting, maintenance work, security and customer service.
application_process: Apply by phone.
required_documents: No Information has been provided by Agency.
eligibility: Homeless and extremely low-income adults.

name: Civicorps Corpsmember Academy
description: Offers a charter high school serving young adults 18-26 years old. Reinforces students' basic academic skills. Teaches students tools and techniques for academic success. Through active research, students also develop a leadership agenda and improvement plan for communities. Students supplement field work by attending evening and Friday classes. Graduates earn a high school diploma.
application_process: Visit the website or call to apply
required_documents: Photo ID, Social Security Card
eligibility: Youth (ages 18-26)

name: College of Alameda (CalWORKs, Health Services, One-Stop Career Center) - (Serving Alameda, Albany, Berkeley, Emeryville & Piedmont)
Community Employment Services Program
description:
Note: Following the ‘Shelter-in-Place’ guidelines and all programs have been suspended till May 31st.  Programs are scheduled to resume in June, but this is all subject to change.  Staff will be reaching out through letters, telephone calls and updated website information.  This is to protect the residents of Alameda County from contracting COVID-19. Posted: 5-4-2020 9:27am SMR 

Provides job search, placement and training, as well as travel training for adults with intellectual and developmental disabilities. Assists in developing employment opportunities with businesses in the community, and matches individuals eager to work with those employers. Provides ongoing job coaching and support at no cost to the individual or company. Provides support such as mobility training to ensure the person can get to the work site, individualized job coaching, education about benefits and responsibilities of SSI/SSA recipients, and referral to independent living skills programs.
application_process: By phone when referred by case manager from RCEB (Regional Center of East Bay, La Familia, or Asian Community Mental Health Services). Must complete application and screening process.
required_documents: Referral required from Regional Center
eligibility: Adults over the age of 22, a resident of Alameda County, a client of the Regional Center of the East Bay, and primary diagnosis of an Intellectual and/or Developmental Disability (program entrance criteria available).

name: Downtown Streets Team
description: Homeless and at-risk Team members 18 and up, beautify Hayward through their work experience program. In return for their volunteer services, they recieve a basic needs stipend and access to Case management and employment services. An individual can get connected with DST by coming to their Weekly Success Meeting, every Tuesday. It is located at the Hayward Area Historical Society, located at 22380 Foothill Blvd, Hayward, CA 94541. The meeting is at 12:30 pm and typically lasts around an hour.
application_process: Walk in.
eligibility: 18 yrs old or older. Come to Tuesday Meeting and get on the waitlist.
schedule: These hours are open for anyone to join their Weekly Success Meeting. This is the entry point of Downtown Streets Team. The program runs throughout the week once someone joins the Team.

name: Education and Support Services
description:
Provides peer support, mentoring, support for textbooks, and school enrollment assistance. Also offers referrals to on-campus support for formerly incarcerated college students. Other support services include:
  • Transportation
  • Referrals to supportive services agencies
  • Financial literacy
  • One-on-one intensive case management
  • Barrier removal to help meet educational goals
  • Referrals to vocational training 
  • High School Completion (Diploma, GED, HiSET)
  • Transition to college and financial aid supports
  • Career training education 
  • English as a second language (ESL)
  • Adult basic education 
  • Academic Counseling
application_process: Visit during program hours
required_documents: No information has been provided by Agency
eligibility:
Must be over the age of 17 and not be a high school graduate.

For First Place for Youth: Must be between the ages of 18 and 24

name: Employment Programs
description: CAF operates a Work Activity Program (WAP). In collaboration with the Regional Center of East Bay and the California Department of Rehabilitation. The Work Activity Program is CARF (Commission on Accreditation of Rehabilitation Facilities) accredited. WAP has been providing individuals with vocational skills and paid work experience. This business division is called Custom Assembly and Packaging (CAP). CAP operates an on-site Assembly and Packaging business at CAF Richmond facility. Working with Custom Assembly and Packaging, individuals enrolled in the WAP program are employed by CAP. Provide packaging, labeling and assembly services for a variety of businesses that have contracted with CAP. Participants earn an income and are provided resources. Enables them to secure more mainstream employment. To augment the participants vocational training and developing employment skills, individuals are provided on-site adult education classes.
application_process: Call for intake
required_documents: No information has been provided by Agency
eligibility: Must be receiving services from the Regional Center of East Bay.

name: Environmental Training Center
description: A youth employment program for youth age 16-24. Youth learn job and life skills through their participation and work on various crews. Services are coordinated with Counseling Center; group counseling sessions are required. Options include: URBAN GARDENING: Youth learn organic farming techniques, sustainable agriculture, and sales and marketing while creating a beautiful area within the community. Youth maintain a produce garden.
application_process: Apply by phone.
required_documents: No information has been provided by Agency.
eligibility: Youth, age 16-24

name: Food Service Training - Berkeley
description: Offers training that focuses on basic culinary, barista and customer service skills for jobs in cafs, restaurants and other food retail businesses. In addition, there is a strong job readiness component that includes resume writing, job search, interviewing, and other skills needed to transition into the food industry. TRAINEE REQUIREMENTS: Must love to cook and bake, be 18 years of age and older, low income, eligible to work in the U.S. or is in the process of getting a work permit, committed to finding a job in the food industry upon graduation, physically able to complete training, for example work on feet for 8 hours a day and lift 25 pounds, drug and alcohol free, free of violent or weapon-related offenses, able to read recipes in English, willing to receive follow-up calls from program staff after graduation. For application information call their training hotline and have a pen and paper 888-283-3522 or email at info@breadproject.org.
application_process: Call 888-283-3522 for application information.
eligibility: See "Trainee Requirements" in Program Description for details.

name: Foster Youth Job Readiness and Employment Referrals
description: Offers employment specialists to assist current and former foster youth and probation youth with all aspects of their job readiness and employment search. Staff helps youth explore vocational interests and options, locate job readiness resources and pursue employment opportunities.
application_process: Walk-in, apply by phone, referred by social worker.
required_documents: None
eligibility: Current and former foster youth and probation youth, age 16-24.

name: Goodwill Academy
description: The Goodwill Academy is a vocational education program tailored to help those with very little work experience. The Program focuses on four major areas: work skills, career development, life skills, and support services. Provides hands-on work skills training at 28 stores and three plants, which enables participants to receive a paycheck while attending program. While attending this training, participants attend Goodwill Academy classes and receive individualized job and career services.
application_process: Visit during program hours. Referral necessary from Social Services Agency for GA.
eligibility: Resident of Alameda County, Contra Costa County or Solano County.

name: Kitchen of Champions Culinary Program
description:
Note: Closed until further notice. Posted 4-10-2020 2:10pm SMR 

Offers a hands-on culinary employment training program. The program helps prepare people for fair-wage positions in the food and hospitality industry. Provides classroom and hands-on training, workforce readiness basics, case management and job placement. Students in the training program get real-world practice, working under a master chef and helping prepare the meals served at the Dining Room.
application_process: Apply by phone.
required_documents: No Information has been provided by Agency.
eligibility: Homeless and extremely low-income adults in Alameda County.

name: Laney College (CalWORKs, Child Care, Health Services, Project Bridge)
description:
Note: Campus Is Closed Until Further Notice. Remote services are now available. Posted: 4-28-2020 4:06pm SMR 

Accredited California community college offers academic education, academic and career counseling, and other support services for diverse students of all ages. Offers associate degrees, certificate programs, career and technical education, and courses transferable to 4-year colleges and universities.  ADMISSIONS & RECORDS: Contact 510-464-3121, Monday-Friday, 8-4:30 or go to Room A109.  CalWORKs PROGRAM: Offers vocational and educational training programs that lead to self-sufficiency. Provides case management, resource referrals, financial aid assistance, employment services, and childcare assistance. Contact 510-986-6946 for more information.  CHILD CARE: Provides free, limited child-care services for pre-school children of qualified full-time students. For more information, contact 510-464-3574.  HEALTH SERVICES offers TB skin testing, stress management, first aid, health checks, weight checks, nutrition counseling, health insurance information, flu immunizations, and family planning. For additional information and appointments call 510-464-3516.  PROJECT BRIDGE provides programs for adults who want to strengthen basic skills in reading, writing, math, computer, and study skills. Contact 510-464-3411 for more information.  FINANCIAL AID INFORMATION: Contact 510-464-3414, e-mail inquiry to laneyfinaid@peralta.edu or go to www.peralta.edu.
application_process: By phone, in person, or online.
eligibility: Age 18 or older, or under age 18 with GED or high school diploma.
schedule: Chancellor; Friday (only drop or pick up any paper); call for hours during peak registration.

description:
Note: Campus is closed to the public. Available online. Posted: 5-1-2020 10:33am SMR 

The Las Positas College CalWORKs program serves CalWORKs students and their families. Provides educational and career opportunities. Offers an array of support services that enable CalWORKs students to:
  • complete their educational goals
  • find meaningful employment
  • transition into the workforce

name: Oakland Women's Center Supportive Services
description: Women's Centers International manages the Oakland Women's Center. Provides free training workshops in four core areas: Business Management and job skills, Adult Education( Literacy, ESL, GED), Health Education for women and response to sexual and domestic violence. They provide referrals for housing and any service that we do not yet directly provide. The center is a safe environment that fosters a cross-cultural sisterhood of support for low-income women who want to build more prosperous lives.
application_process: Visit during program hours or call to apply
eligibility: Must be female.

name: One Stop Shop (One-Stop Career Center/Transfer Center and Puente Program)
Opportunity Build
description: A pre-apprenticeship training program that prepares unemployed and under-employed adults with barriers to employment for entry-level jobs in the construction, energy efficiency and solar industries and for union apprenticeships. GETS provides classroom and hands-on training / technical training. During the 9 to 11 weeks of training, participants learn basic construction skills, earn OSHA 10 and First Aid/CPR certifications, strengthen applied math skills and work on employment readiness. During and after classroom training, participants receive 12 months of case management and job placement support from GETS staff who help in identifying and securing employment and union apprenticeship opportunities.
application_process: Phone, walk in, by appointment or referral.
required_documents: No information has been provided by agency
eligibility: must be 18 or older with HS Diploma/GED, Valid I.D and Social Security card.

name: Police Explorer Program
description:
Offers leadership programs to prepare students to be active in the community, learn more about law enforcement career, obtain valuable work experience, and take on more responsibility as a young adult. Basic volunteering includes:
  • Ride-Alongs
  • Traffic Control
  • Evidence Searches and more
application_process: Call Officer Iain Fry to apply.

-Must be between ages 14-19
-Must be enrolled in high school and maintain a 2.00-grade point average or higher OR
-Possess a high school diploma or GED with qualifying scores
-Must demonstrate a good level of responsibility and maturity

name: Refugee Employment Services
description:
Provides refugees with job search skills, employment counseling, job development, and job placement to help them effectively integrate into American life. Also assists with job retention. Vocational ESL provided at Oakland office. Services also provided in Spanish at Oakland office.

March 11, 2020

Dear Members of our Community:
As the news of the coronavirus (COVID-19) continues to evolve, we at Catholic Charities East Bay are making efforts to protect the health of our staff and of our community.
We are therefore cancelling all walk-in consultation and housing clinics through the end of March.
Individual appointments and other business operations will continue, unless additional advisories suggest limiting in-person activity.
 
Please call us for more information later in the month of March to determine when our clinics will resume.
Thank you for your understanding.
Stay well.

2-1-1 Alameda County
description:
Notes: No change to programs. Posted: 4-13-2020 3:29pm SMR

2-1-1 is a free three-digit phone number, available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week to anyone in need. 2-1-1 provides information and referrals to programs and services available in the county including: transitional, subsidized, and permanent low-cost housing; health and social services; rental and utility assistance; public assistance programs; food and much more. 2-1-1 updates shelter availability twice a day for emergency shelters (individual, family or domestic violence).

Specialized portals available at http://211alamedacounty.org/

Reentry Services http://reentry.211alamedacounty.org

Transportation Services http://transportation.211alamedacounty.org

Listos 4 Steps to Emergency Preparedness for All  http://211alamedacounty.org/4steps/

AHIP provides housing and social service referrals for people with HIV or AIDS. Maintains a database of AIDS-dedicated housing which is updated monthly. In addition, AHIP also has access to Eden I&R's database of low-income and market rate housing units that are not specifically for people with HIV. AHIP facilitates several housing workshops for case managers and clients throughout the county. Call AHIP for current schedule of roving sites, days, and hours.

name: Eden Low Cost Housing
description:
Note: Office is closed to the public. Call for more information. 
Posted: 4-10-2020 3:31pm SMR

Offers rental apartment communities in cities throughout Alameda County and the greater Bay Area at affordable rents. Links managed housing with resources that support residents in their daily lives.  Resident support programs are provided free of charge at many Eden Housing developments. Resident Service Coordinators offer on-site information and referral, and implement programs including:
  • youth summer and after-school activities
  • an innovative computer-assisted learning program
  • a scholarship program for deserving adult students
  • financial literacy training
  • support for the frail elderly as well as a variety of community building events
IF INTERESTED IN AN EXISTING PROPERTY: Apply directly at property when that property's waiting list is "open." Check for "open" waiting list status online at www.edenhousing.org. Look under "NOW LEASING", or obtain a list of such properties in person at 22645 Grand Street, Hayward. Information is updated monthly.
application_process: Eden Housing does not rent from a central location. For existing properties: apply directly at property when that property's waiting list is open. For waiting list status (open/closed): go online, call or walk in to office for list. For interest list on properties being developed: call by phone. See Program Description for further details. Approximately six months prior to the completion of that development, a flyer will be mailed to clients on the "interest list," outlining the application procedure and timeline.
required_documents: No Information has been provided by Agency.
eligibility: Low-income families, adult individuals, seniors and persons with disabilities. Visit website for Resident Selection Criteria policy, established to comply with federal and state laws and/or Eden Housing company policy.

name: Housing Department
description:
Notes: No change to programs. Posted: 4-13-2020 3:29pm SMR

Property Owners: In our effort to assist community members in securing housing Eden I&R maintains a housing database to provide 2-1-1 callers with vacancies or open waiting lists. Local property owners and developers can list their vacancies and open waiting lists with Eden I&R for free.  There are three solid advantages to listing vacancies with Eden I&R, 1. Additional Exposure: Last year 211 Alameda County received approximately 50,000 calls from community members seeking housing.  2. Saves Property Owners Time: Only callers who meet the owner’s general guidelines are referred.  3. Saves Property Owners Money: The housing referral service is free to property owners and community members. To list a property call 510-727-9565, email housing@edenir.org. or fill out online form at www.edenir.org or www.achousingchoices.org.

Agencies: Housing Subscriptions are intended for community-based organizations and other direct service providers seeking a comprehensive source of affordable housing information for their clients. A one-year subscription includes 24 installments (biweekly) of the PDF document and/or the hard copy of all the housing listings in our database for an annual fee. Fees are on a sliding scale based on the size of the agency, refer to www.edenir.org for subscription fees.

211 callers in need of housing: Eden I&R manages a database of over 87,000 housing units mostly located throughout Alameda County. Eden I&R lists affordable properties managed and developed by local  housing authorities, affordable developers and landlords to add vacancies and open waiting lists to the housing database. Although the priority is affordable housing, Eden I&R lists: 1. Property owners that work with rental subsidy programs and 2. Property owners that offer fair market rate rentals. By simply calling 2-1-1 the public can access these vacancies and waiting lists 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. The housing listings can also be accessed on Eden I&R’s housing website, www.achousingchoices.org.
application_process: Call to apply

eligibility: Open to all.

name: Housing Division
description: FIRST TIME HOMEBUYER LOAN PROGRAM (FTHLP) provides financial assistance, in the form of a deferred loan, for first time homebuyers within a certain income range who are in the process of buying a new home in Dublin.  FTHLP is capable of offering up to 10% of the purchase price for a Market Rate home, and up to 15% of the purchase price for a Below Market Rate home, with a $40,000 maximum loan amount for both Market Rate and Below Market Rate homes.  Eligibility Requirements include but are not limited to: (1) Must be a first-time homebuyer (a household that has not owned a residential property/home within the past three years); (2) must be able to qualify for a City-approved mortgage loan program (30-year fixed); and (3) must provide a minimum of 3.5% of the sales price as a down payment. For further requirements, please refer to the application packet.  TRI-VALLEY RENTAL HOUSING opportunities guide provides a listing of affordable housing-related services in the Tri-Valley area, including fair housing resources; a listing of affordable rental units in the Tri-Valley area; and information regarding emergency housing and resources available to Tri-Valley residents. Directory is free and available online.
application_process: Below market rate rental and ownership housing. First time homebuyer loan program. See www.dublin.ca.gov/housing or call for applications. Rental applications are obtained through the rental community.
eligibility: Below market rate rental and ownership housing. First time home buyer loan program. See www.dublin.ca.gov/housing for eligibility.

name: City of Berkeley's Housing Retention Program
description:
Note: Office is closed to the public but still assisting clients. Call and leave a message for further assistance. Posted: 4-29-2020 11:21am SMR 

The City of Berkeley’s Housing Retention Program now has funds available through June 30,
2018. This program provides financial assistance to Berkeley tenants to prevent eviction due
to non-payment of rent or failed inspection due to hoarding. Grants are available to
households that meet the eligibility criteria below. Submitting an application does not
guarantee financial assistance. Application approval requires that each program requirement
be met and supporting verifiable documentation provided.
Eligibility Requirements ;
 - Berkeley residents or Berkeley S+C/Rapid Rehousing tenants who are at imminent risk of losing their permanent housing.
 - Income must be verified by documentation from a third party.
 - Household requesting assistance must have a signed rental agreement. If not, lease
holder must submit copy of rental agreement and documentation verifying applicant’s
tenancy and monthly rent.
 - Monthly income must support monthly expenses.
 - Grant must prevent an eviction.
 - Households must meet one or more of the following requirements and provide
supporting documentation verifying below criteria.
 - Decrease in income
 - Unexpected medical and/or disability expenses paid without credit.
 - Fleeing domestic violence
 - Work-related vehicle expense (vehicle is required for the job supporting
documentation from employer may be required)
 - Other unexpected significant expenses may be considered eligible.
Documentation needed for Application:
 -Completed Application.
 - Picture ID for all household members older than 18.
 - Verification of Current Income for all income included in the budget sheet.
 - A dated Notice of Eviction from landlord stating amount owned for back rent. A 3-day notice of eviction  is  recommended. The Notice of Eviction must be dated in the current month.
 - Rental Agreement or Lease. If applicant is not on the lease, the lease holder must submit a signed dated letter indicating applicant’s portion of the rent and rent due. If Section 8 Housing or Shelter Plus Care, copy of Housing Assistance Payments (HAP) Agreement.
 - W-9 Form (Tax I.D.) signed by landlord.
 - Proof of Building Ownership is needed if not a BHA property.
 - Documentation showing decrease in income, unexpected medical/disability expense,
fleeing domestic violence, or work-related vehicle expense.
 - You may be asked to provide additional documentation to support your application for
financial assistance.
If you meet the eligibility criteria above and wish to apply for rental assistance, please contact East Bay Community Law Center at 510-548-4040 and ask for Housing Intake.
Approved households can receive up to $5,000 as a one-time grant.
application_process: If you meet the eligibility criteria above and wish to apply for rental assistance, please call 510-548-4040 and ask for Housing Intake.

Provides advocacy for repairs and relief from uninhabitable housing. Drop-in Housing Law Clinics are offered Thursdays.

NOTE: All offices are closed but continue to take calls at general number 510-437-1554. Staff will return calls M-F, 9-5 PM. Also can email at info@centrolegal.org. Legal consultation provided over the phone but no longer at on-site clinics (until April 7).  Posted 3/24/2020, 12:46 PM, pg

Procedures for leaving a message: If a client did not pick up the phone, or if information otherwise needs to be relayed without the client present, the HRC should leave a message stating that:
  1. The client may be eligible for SSVF
  2. An SSVF provider will follow up with the client using the same contact info that the HRC has
  3. They can contact the SSVF provider using the contact information below
  4. They can decline the offer of SSVF by contacting the HRC, or through the SSVF provider once the SSVF provider reaches out to them

name: West Oakland Community Information/Referral Services
description: The West Oakland Community Information Center works with a variety of participants, businesses, vendors and agencies in Oakland. Some of their services include: information on employment opportunities, free meal agencies information, housing/shelter referral, contact information for agencies that assist with first and last month rent deposit, provide medical and education information, contact information for agencies that assist with utility payments, assist eligible clients with clean slate (removal) of criminal record, Early Head Start and a variety of referrals for other socioeconomic services during these challenging times today.The West Oakland Community Information Center serves the community in OWH's front office on 8th Street. The goal of the the information center, is to help people make healthy life style choices, retain their independence, integrity, and overcome adversity.

description:
NOTE: Women’s Daytime Drop-in Center
  • Free meals, food, and hygiene/cleaning supplies available through a pick-up window for women and children experiencing homelessness in Berkeley.
  • Visit on Monday-Friday between 8:00am-4:00pm to receive assistance.
  • 2218 Acton Street, Berkeley, CA 94702; phone #: 510-548-2884; hours: Monday-Friday from 8:00am-4:00pm.

Posted: 4/13/2020, 1:25 PM, ar

Offers a safe and peaceful home-like environment for homeless women and children and the marginally housed. Also offer a healthy breakfast and lunch Monday-Friday. hygiene kits, diapers, and mail service are available upon request.  
 
Their staff offers assistance with providing and locating community resources: making proper referrals to agencies who can better assist the clients, mental health outreach, public health nurses, aging services, BACS housing workshops, and available housing wait lists. 
 
Other services they offer include a variety of groups: parenting, empowerment, and domestic violence support.

name: Affordable Public Housing Program
description:
Note: Offering services via phone, email and mail. Visit the website https://www.cityofberkeley.info/bha/ for more information how people can contact their case worker directly. Section 8 participants in Berkeley cannot stop paying their rent due to COVID 19. They have to contact their case worker and their case worker will adjustment the amount of rent the participant has to pay based on their current income. 

Administers two basic types of housing programs. Services available to low-income individuals and families, seniors (age 62 or over) and disabled persons:
  • Tenant-Based Assistance
  • Project-Based Assistance

TENANT-BASED ASSISTANCE OR SECTION 8 HOUSING CHOICE VOUCHER PROGRAM:
Tied to the family who receives the freedom of searching for affordable housing among all rental housing within Berkeley Housing Authority's jurisdiction. Provides Section 8 unit listings on website.

PROJECT-BASED ASSISTANCE
Tied to a specific dwelling. The family who lives there will pay an affordable rent, but if they move, they receive no further rental assistance. The unit then goes to the next income-eligible family who moves in. The rent paid by families is based on household income. Rent is generally between 30% to 40% of the familyÆs monthly adjusted gross income. Also offers Moderate Rehabilitation (Mod Rehab) SRO Program.
application_process: Apply for voucher or only after seeing announcement in newspaper or other media. Apply for Moderate Rehabilitation Housing (MOD) by completing an Interest Card at UA Homes. MOD list is open continuously.
required_documents: None
eligibility: Very low-income family, elderly (age 62 or over), disabled for voucher or public housing program. Very low-income homeless individuals for Mod Rehab program.

description:
Note: Winter shelter is closed but Due to COVID 19 they are treating this program as a drop in center where people can get breakfast and lunch. Posted: 4-29-2020 10:52am SMR 

Open December 2, 2019 - April 15, 2020
Offers homeless shelter for adult men and women when temperatures drops below 40 degrees or it is rainy weather (over 50% chance of rain at night). Shelter will always be open on Mondays and Thursdays.  No pets allowed. Serves hot meals for dinner and quick breakfast before guests leave. 

Not a drop-in shelter. Guests must pre-register. Also offers the Alameda Laundry Program (645 Central Ave in Alameda EVERY Thursday starting at 10am. One load per person only. Last load goes in at 12:15pm)

The shelter will close on June 30, 2020 and reopen on Dec. 1, 2020.
At FPCH we have dinner and breakfast served at the shelter and during the day we have a resource center is open from 10-4 M-F where lunch is served.  There are showers on Wednesdays from 2-6.

Showers are available on 2nd and 4th Sundays, must sign up day of to be considered. No pets allowed.

NOTE: Shelter was reopened on June 6th and will be closing June 30th, 2020.  They plan on reopening again on Dec. 1, 2020. SHP will open a resource center on the 8th M-F from 10-4.  Posted 6/10/2020, 2:44 PM, pg

Offers meals to guests.Clients must be out by 7am the following morning. Security and Shelter Coordinator will be on site at all times. Clean and sober environment. No drinking/drugs, no pets, no minors (must be at least 18).

name: 24 Hour Emergency Shelter Program (Twenty-four)
description: SHELTER ADDRESS IS CONFIDENTIAL AND THEREFORE NOT PROVIDED.  Provides 17-bed short-term emergency shelter for single women, women with children (children 11 and under), and permanent, affordable (Section 8) housing in two houses. Shelter and services offered to women who are at risk for homelessness due to domestic violence, loss of job and income, or wages so low they cannot afford housing. Offers parenting classes, workshops and childcare. Workshops include self-esteem, resume writing, landlord-tenant relationships, and housekeeping. Residents must be clean and sober for 90 days and willing to volunteer within the agency. House meetings held weekly. Also provides referrals to outside counseling. Assists clients through the process of obtaining permanent housing.  Does not serve transgender women.
application_process: Apply by phone; appointment necessary.
eligibility: Low-income woman, homeless woman or woman with child, age 11 or under. Must be clean and sober for 90 days and willing to volunteer within the agency; need to have proof of negative TB test or clean chest x-ray.
schedule: Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, 10am-5pm (These are the only days for shelter intakes if available)

name: 24-Hour Mobile Response Team (MRT)
description:
NOTE: Hotline is open.  
FVLC offices are closed during the crisis, although the Alameda County Family Justice Center continues to remain open to walk-in clients at 470 27th St. Oakland, CA 94612 from 8:30am to 5pm Monday through Friday. We recommend that all clients needing help from FVLC be referred to our 24 hour crisis line number at 1-800-947-8301 where we continue to have advocates assisting survivors or domestic violence and sexual assault throughout Alameda County at all times. We are still also providing remote legal services and answering legal questions related to domestic violence restraining orders and family law for survivors. Please let us know if you have any other clarifying questions.
Posted: 3/30/2020, 1:33 PM, ar
Certified and trained domestic violence counselors will assist with crisis counseling, safety planning, emergency relocation for those in immediate danger, which consist of finding shelter and possibly other critical needs. If a victim calls Family Violence Law Center a counselor will assist in seeking a shelter in Alameda County as well as surrounding counties.
application_process: By phone.

name: Domestic Violence Shelter - Women with Children (boys up to age 10)

required_documents: Drivers License or state ID
eligibility: Any one in need of a shelter; and or fleeing a domestic violence situation. Male child can be up to age 10

name: Emergency Shelter
description:
SAVE's 30-bed shelter offers a safe home, for up to 90 days, while individuals and families fleeing abuse begin to heal. Provides food, shelter, and clothing, as well as services and support to assist clients through time of crisis. Shelter services include counseling, referrals, goal-setting, financial literacy and job-readiness workshops, parenting skills, and problem-solving techniques.  In case the shelter is full or they are unable to accommodate the individual or family, SAVE will attempt to assist victims to find other suitable shelter. Service animals accepted, location is confidential. Also serves transgender individuals who are living their lives as women.

NOTE:
In response to COVID-19, at this time, our Empowerment Center is closed. Our business lines (510) 574-2250 are still receiving calls and will be handling as much of our normal business as we can remotely. Anyone needing emergency support due to domestic violence should call our hotline (510)794-6055. This line is staffed 24/7 and will be operating as it normally does.

Our Safe House is currently full and we will continue to shelter the residents through this crisis and beyond. Posted 3/24/2020, 3:20 PM, pg
application_process: By phone.
required_documents: No information has been provided by Agency.
eligibility: Victim of domestic violence.

name: Emergency Shelter
description:
Note: All services are being provided by phone and online. 
Posted: 4-10-2020 3:42pm SMR 

Provides emergency shelter for up to 90 days to battered victims with or without children that are in danger and have no other resources; only takes in victims of intimate partner violence, not violence by a non-intimate family member (mom, brother, etc). Provides assistance accessing alternative domestic violence shelter accommodation. Service animals only accepted if verifying documents can be provided. Shelter location is confidential. Also provides food, clothing and basic necessities, referrals for emergency medical needs, counseling, case management, emergency transportation to and from the shelter and other safe locations, assistance with legal and court needs (including restraining orders and child custody matters), resource assistance (including CalWORKs eligibility assessment), children's program (including counseling), and daily support groups. Residents participate in cleaning and cooking. Assists with transition to and establishment of household. Includes rental and housing referrals and advocacy. Offers safety planning, including relocation arrangements from batterer's or client's residence. Once housing is secured, provides household items as needed/available.
application_process: Call to apply. Intake 9am-2pm.
required_documents: No information has been provided by Agency.
eligibility: Battered victims with or without children (accept boys under 17); only take in victims of intimate partner violence, not violence by a non-intimate family member (mom, brother, etc).

name: Rape Crisis Services
description: Provides crisis intervention and advocacy services to survivors of sexual assault and abuse. Offers safe environment for survivors to talk. Supportive services include 24-hour crisis line, advocacy, individual counseling, information, and aid to friends and family. Educates the community on these issues. SEXUAL ASSAULT RESPONSE TEAM (SART) is called to respond when a rape survivor reports to the police station or hospital. Aims to reduce the number of times that a survivor must tell her or his story. SART advocates assists rape survivor through the emotional, medical and legal process following an assault. The relationship and conversations between survivor and advocate are confidential, protected by law, and cannot be brought up in court. SART is an alliance between Valley Care Hospital, Tri-Valley Police and Sheriff's Departments, and the District Attorney's Office.
application_process: By phone.
required_documents: No information has been provided by Agency.
eligibility: Victim of sexual assault.
schedule: 24 hours a day, 7 days a week

Note: Program is currently full and not accepting clients. Call for more information.

Operates 24-hour crisis hotline, Takes weekend intakes on an emergency basis. Provides information and referral, housing assistance, job training, referrals and placement. Also offers supportive counseling for domestic violence, homelessness and parenting issues.

name: Shiloh Domestic Violence Shelter and Services
description: Houses and supports women and children that are victims of domestic violence. Length of stay is up to 105 days (approximately 3-1/2 months), with weekly evaluations. Situated in a safe and confidential location. Provides emergency food, clothing, and personal items. Each resident has access to a counselor that works individually during counseling sessions, and a case manager to assist in meeting housing, legal, vocational, and financial needs. Also serves lesbian survivors of intimate partner violence and transgender survivors that are living lives as women. Service animals accepted. Does not provide transportation to shelter (no pick up, no tax voucher, etc) except from a neutral meeting location in the Tri-Valley area.
application_process: Apply by phone for initial screening. Follow-up with in-person intake meeting in neutral location. Can accept from another domestic violence shelter.

eligibility: Victim of domestic or intimate partner violence only; accepts boys under 18.
schedule: Toll free crisis line available 24 hours daily.

name: Sister Me Home Safe House
description:
Note: Continue to provide vulnerable individuals and families with shelter, safety, food, and community at five emergency shelters. Housing programs and domestic violence services are at full capacity. Posted: 4-29-2020 9:52am SMR 

Sister Me Home is open 24 hours daily offering 20 beds for women and women with children surviving domestic violence. It is one of few programs in Alameda County to serve battered women with substance abuse issues who have not had 30 days clean and sober. Serves 3 meals a day and provide safety planning, confidential mail service, showers, laundry, clothing, case management, support groups and children's activities. Length of stay is 29 days with the possibility of extension depending on safety needs and progress with case plan. Open to screening transgender women (who are living their lives as women) for shelter services. Service animals may be accepted if verifying documents are provided.
application_process: Call crisis line for availability.

description:

Provides support services to clients to become fully self-sufficient, including:
  • On-site Case Management
  • Life Skills Education
  • A Host of Other Services

name: CityServe Support Services
description:
Coordinates resources, including motel vouchers when available, volunteers between the faith-based community, non-profits, schools, businesses and government agencies to meet human service needs and connecting volunteers in the local church and community to the non-profits in their Tri-Valley. Serves individuals/families in crisis situations for emergency motel nights (they do not provide motel vouchers, they pay direct to motels specific to individuals/families), helps with rent to avoid displacement, and with utilities to avoid service shut off. Also offers auto repair, auto donations when available, transportation assistance (Bus, Bart tickets), emergency food (Gift cards). 

NOTE: Refer homeless clients who are in Tri-Valley only and they will put them on a list for motel vouchers.  Do not make any promises because the medically fragile will be given priority.  Refer to other agencies for food, if possible. Working with their current caseload to provide food and are swamped.   Posted 3/25/2020, 5:22 PM, pg
application_process: By phone, online and by appointment.  Appointment will be required for financial assistance.
required_documents: Photo identification, copy of lease or rental agreement if rental assistance is requested.
eligibility: Dublin, Livermore, Pleasanton, San Ramon, Danville, & Alamo residents. Financial need must be demonstrated.

name: Covenant House California / Oakland Shelter
description: Offers 24/7 residential shelter and case management to youth. Services include housing, employment, medical and mental health. Staff never turns eligible youth away, providing youth emergency overnight accommodations.  Outreach teams work with youth to find shelter beds, get housing, or problem-solve current situations.
application_process: Visit during program hours
required_documents: No information has been provided by Agency
eligibility: Homeless youth age 18-24.

name: COVID Isolation Housing
description:
NOTE: Additional isolation program called Operation Homebase is sometimes referred to as “The State Trailers” or “The FEMA Trailers”. This is a COVID-19 isolation trailer program located in East Oakland. The management and programmatic staff is provided by Housing Consortium of the East Bay (HCEB). NO referrals made through 211.  

Operation Comfort and Operation Safer Ground are Alameda County’s COVID-19 isolation housing. Now available for referral agencies who serve people experiencing homelessness (literally homeless as defined by CES).

Operation Comfort is ONLY for homeless people who are either Covid-19 positive or it's presumed they have it due to exposure. Must have the following criteria: 
  • Tested positive for COVID-19 OR
  • Experiencing symptoms of COVID-19 OR
  • Been exposed to COVID-19

Operation Safer Ground is ONLY for homeless people who are not positive or presumptive, but who are at the greatest risk of contracting Covid-19 such as those over 65 and those with specific health conditions.

For a list of approved referral agencies click here. 
For Covid Isolation housing questions email achch@acgov.org

For the protection of onsite staff and the recovery of current patients, no walk-ins will be accepted. 

**The referral process remains unchanged.  211 is unable to make direct referrals to either Operation Comfort or Safer Ground.  The referral process for 211 includes directing actual homeless callers who express concern they are Covid-19 positive to calling their primary care physician or if they do not have one of those, calling one of the clinics or hospitals that are able to refer.  They can also call  Alameda County Health Care for the Homeless Monday to Friday from 9 am – 4 pm at:  (510) 891-8950.**
application_process:
Referring Agencies will:
For clients who meet eligibility criteria, contact your agency or program's designated referral liaison. They can inform authorized staff how to complete the referral
process.
For clients who do not meet eligibility criteria, the county is working diligently on efforts to expand capacity. Guidance will be provided once available.
required_documents: No information has been provided by Agency
eligibility:
Open to Homeless individuals who have:
Tested positive for COVID-19 OR
Experiencing symptoms of COVID-19 OR
Been exposed to COVID-19

Operation Comfort is ONLY for homeless people who are either Covid-19 positive or it's presumed they have it due to exposure.

Operation Safer Ground is ONLY for homeless people who are not positive or presumptive, but who are at the greatest risk of contracting Covid-19 such as those over 65 and those with specific health conditions.
schedule:
Referrals must be received by 7 pm for same day screening.
Referrals received after 7 pm will be screened the following
workday.

name: Crossroads Emergency Shelter
description:
Note: Not doing walk ins until futher notice. Only accepting referrals made by 211. Posted: 4-10-2020 4:39pm SMR 

Assists homeless families, veterans, and people living with HIV/AIDS recover from homelessness and achieve self-reliance and independence.
Note: HIV/AIDS Shelter Beds must be referred to AHIP Dept for assistance
Services also provide other special programs when available GA, CHASS, BHC and VA. Continuum of care services include: case management, life skills training, access to medical and dental care, mental health and substance abuse counseling, income and housing referrals, and career counseling. Single residents share dorm rooms during stay. Families live in a separate residential wing that holds five rooms (each with a private bathroom), a learning center, a play area and shared area for socializing. Also provides showers, laundry facilities, lockers, computers and Internet access.
application_process: By phone for bed availability. Can also apply through Alameda County Community Housing and Support Services (CHASS) at the following locations: Eastmont Self-Sufficiency Center, 6955 Foothill Blvd., Suite 100, Oakland, 888-999-4772 or 510-383-5300; Alameda County Social Services, 24100 Amador Street, Hayward.
required_documents: No information has been provided by Agency
eligibility: Open to all. Priority is given to clients assessed as LH or at imminent risk of becoming Literally Homeless. Will work with those needing assessments after arrival.  Priority also given to persons released from hospitals, it is on a case by case basis.

name: Dwight Way Women and Mens Shelter
description: Offers shelter services for Single Men and Women (32 beds for women).  Please be aware only one backpack per entry, and no outside bedding (enforcing bed bug policy). Temperature will be checked upon arrival during health screening.
application_process: Call for bed availability
required_documents: No Information Provided by Agency
eligibility: Open to Single Men or Women screened as Literally Homeless
schedule: Call the shelter Reservation hotline Monday-Friday, between 7pm & 8pm and weekends between 2pm & 3pm

name: Emergency Shelter
description:
Note: Office is open to the public. All Drug testing, domestic violence and DUI programs have been postponed until further notice. Group meetings are reduced to follow social distancing guidelines. Posted: 4-10-2020 4:13pm SMR 

Provides a multi-purpose homeless shelter which provides 30 beds for single adults and families. Serves anyone not having an appropriate place to live. There is no other requirement, although the program has a special focus on persons in recovery from drug and alcohol problems. Basic stay is two weeks for singles and three weeks for families. Flexibility depends on residents' particular situation. Basic services include bed, three meals daily, laundry, telephone and mail drop. Also provides information to community resources and support services. Subject to availability, shelter provides limited access for non-residents to shower, do laundry and eat an evening meal.
application_process: By phone for availability.
required_documents: No information has been provided by Agency.
eligibility: Anyone not having an appropriate place to live.

name: FESCO Family Emergency Shelter (Les Marquis House)
description:
Note: FESCO is open and continues to provide Essential Services to homeless families during this time. Posted: 4-29-2020 4:23pm SMR 

Offers short term emergency shelter for unhoused families. Program offers supportive services,which include daily meals, case management, housing, employment, benefits referrals and resources, children's programs, and counseling.
Service animals may be accepted if verifying documents are provided.
application_process: Families should contact shelter directly for phone interview and program overview. Accepts self-referrals and outside referrals for screening.
required_documents: It is preferred that families begin process of gathering documents such as ID, birth certificates prior to and upon entry as well as contacting the nearest HRC for screening/assessment.
eligibility: Homeless, very low-income family accompanied by minor child/pregnant women 28-40 weeks. Commitment toward goal of securing permanent housing. Resident of Alameda County.  Families may be sharing space with other families

name: Garden Street Center Oakland - Emergency Shelter for Families
description:
Offers emergency shelter to families with children for stays up to 6 months. Reviews and evaluations every 2-weeks. Three meals a day are served to persons in the shelter, mandatory. Family time program is available Monday-Friday, 6pm-7:45pm.

Families seeking shelter must call after 5 PM for an initial screening and to schedule an appointment. Clients may only use the shelter once every eighteen months.
application_process: Call 211.
required_documents: No information has been provided by Agency.
eligibility: Family with children under 18. Clients may use the shelter only once every eighteen months.

name: Immigrant Sanctuary House
description:
NOTE: Hours of Operation: 9:00 AM - 5:00 PM.
Posted: 6/1/2020, 2:28 PM, ar

Provides a sanctuary house, assistance with basic needs and community orientation for Spanish speaking or Latin American refugees and immigrants and children with parents. Offers 9 beds and meals free of charge to house guests for 2-4 months. Offers companionship and volunteer assistance in meeting legal, employment, permanent housing, physical and mental health needs. Serves as a community center offering religious and social events, and educational talks on immigrant issues. Also serves hot meals two times a week, Mondays and Wednesdays to anyone who comes to the door. On Thursdays offers a grocery give away,
application_process: Walk in.
required_documents: Case by case basis
eligibility: Spanish speaking immigrant or refugee recently arrived in the United States with a desire to find employment, age 20 or over. Priority given to homeless person, woman and those without resources or job. Eligibility determined on a case by case basis.

name: Lake Merritt Community Cabins
description: Offers shelter to homeless single adults.
application_process: Call to apply
required_documents: No information has been provided by Agency
eligibility: Must be single adult (18 and over)

name: Livermore Safe Overnight Parking Program
description:
NOTE: Service still in operation, call the main cityserve number.  Posted 4/1/2020, 10:45 AM, pg

Provides families and/or individuals living in their vehicles a safe place to park overnight. Provides overnight parking at seven rotating locations throughout Livermore. Offers safety ambassador to provide security and access to restrooms. Program availability is on a first-come, first-serve basis and may accommodate 10-30 vehicles depending on the site.
application_process:
Call or email to register. Meetings by appointment only. Availability is on a first-come, first-serve basis.

Once enrolled, clients must sign the Rules and Standards of Behavior for the program and receive a parking permit and schedule of sites. Parking permits will be renewed every couple of months to ensure participant information is up to date.
required_documents: Vehicle registration and proof of insurance. Proof of current vaccinations for pets.
eligibility: Homeless Livermore residents living in their vehicles. Pets allowed, must prove animals are current on vaccinations. Vehicle size limits enforced, no RV's allowed.

name: Men's Housing Program (MHP)
description:
Note: 32 beds are available in the men's shelter. Due to COVID-19 there will be no new admits. Shelter available 24/7.

Provides safe, clean short-term residential housing, meals, clothing, laundry and shower facilities to 36 adult men nightly. Clients receive individualized case management, access to employment counseling and life skills training. Encourages every resident to participate in services to achieve permanent housing.
application_process: Call SRS (Shelter Reservation System) until beds are filled.
required_documents: Men must have referral from the Shelter Reservation System (SRS) and arrive at time given by SRS personnel.
eligibility: Homeless man 18 years or older; active participation in housing program and ability to attend to ones physical needs; no ID required.

name: North County Shelter - St. Vincent de Paul Society
description:
Note: Must use hand sanitizer upon entry. No one with a cough or fever will be allowed in. 
Updated: 4-10-2020 2:09pm SMR 

NORTH COUNTY SHELTER  - open 7 days a week year round

SHELTER DOORS ARE OPEN TO CLIENTS WITH RESERVATIONS AT 6 PM EVERY EVENING. DO NOT LINE-UP BEFORE 5:30PM. 

FIRST-TIME CLIENTS ARE NOT ELIGIBLE FOR RESERVATIONS.  First-Time clients, must line up as a  walk up client to meet with Shelter Manager in order to stay first night when unreserved beds are available.  After doing an intake during 1st night stay as a walk up, client may then be eligible to sign-up thru the reservation system in the future.
  •  Shelter doors open to clients with reservations by 6:00 PM each evening
  • Some beds may be available on a walk up, first-come first-served basis
  • Serves adult men and women only
  • (no minors, no children, no persons under 18 years old)
  • No out and ins allowed after entering
  • Evening and morning snack served daily.
  • No client storage, only 2 bags per client allowed, all belongings must fit under a cot and be removed daily.
  • The shelter closes by 8:00 AM every morning, everyone must leave the area until open again in the evening
Shelter Reservation Line 510-638-7600
ONLY those who are eligible to make a reservation should contact reservation line.
All others must be a walk up client for first nights stay, and do an intake with Shelter Manager

 
Please note that the referral agencies listed below may also have remaining reservation beds available at the shelter. Only Clients who are eligible for reservations should contact the below agencies directly for additional beds which may be available.
  • Operation Dignity (OD) - 12 Reservation Beds
  • Berkeley Food and Housing - 5 Reservation Beds
  • Oakland Housing Assistance Center (OHAC) - 3 Reservation Beds
application_process: By phone.
required_documents: No information has been provided by Agency
eligibility: Anyone in need, age 18 or over. No Children allowed. Intake required by Shelter Manager to be eligable for reservation beds.  Until eligible for reservation bed, clients can get in line and attempt to get an available walk up bed

name: North County Winter Shelter Referral Program (OPEN YEAR-ROUND)
description: Acts as one of the referring agencies to the North County Winter Shelter in Oakland. These agencies determine if client is eligible for referral to the North County Winter Shelter. Length of stay for all clients that are eligible to remain at the North County Winter Shelter is for a period of 28 days. Clients are eligible for extensions at the shelter on a case-by-case basis.
application_process: Apply by phone or walk in on Wednesday drop in hours, 9am-5pm, first come first serve.
required_documents: Referral required from SVDP or Operation Dignity
eligibility: Senior, have a disablity or major disabling condition, who is homeless in Oakland.
schedule: These are the hours for the main OD office, where people are referred to the shelter. Shelter is open overnight.

name: One night emergency shelter bed
description:
Coronavirus Update: Due to the COVID-19 Pandemic no new clients will be accepted until futher notice. 

Offers a one night emergency shelter bed on a first come, first served basis. Emergency beds are not always available every night.

Emergency beds filled through the Hotline Monday-Thursday will be for one night only.  Emergency beds filled on Friday night will be through Sunday night.
application_process: Call for bed availability
required_documents: No Information has been provided by Agency.

name: Rescue Mission-Men's Shelter
description:
NOTE: Cityteam Minstries are not accepting any new clients and haven't been for the last month due to shelter in place order. They will not lift this restriction until after the SIP order is lifted.  

Note: Now providing to-go meals from kitchen so that we may continue daily meal service to people in the most need in the community. Now shifted to a drive-thru approach for pre-bagged grocery pick-up process across our 13 mobile pantry sites. Residential programs continue to operate under shelter-in-place guidelines with everyone doing their part. Continue to operate overnight shelter within the public health guidelines that have been established. 

Provides meals, clothing and showers to homeless men. Provides emergency and transitional shelter for men, including showers and loaner clothing. Provides hot breakfast and dinner. Also offers Chapel as a place for spiritual discipleship, worship and opportunities for service. Check in for beds beginning at 4pm with a $5 fee. Do not screen for Sex offenders.
application_process: Visit during program hours In-person, first-come, first-served beds available at 4pm.
required_documents: No Information has been provided by Agency.
eligibility: Low-income homeless male, age 18 or over. Must be able to take care of their own needs and hygiene (bathe, go to the bathroom, etc).

name: Short-term Emergency Shelter - Homeless Single Women and Single Mothers with Children
description:
Note: Currently not accepting new clients. Program is full. 
Posted: 4-10-2020 2:29pm SMR 

Single women and single mothers with children are encouraged to participate in programs and services designed to help find solutions through extensive, discipleship and recovery programs. Program offers: recovery from homelessness and its causes, including peer counseling, Biblical Studies, education, job-and-life skills training and more. Also screens for Sex offenders.
application_process: By phone or in person for availability.

NOTE: Staff member Jesus Garcia.said they are continuing to stay open for current cleints.  Not taking any new clients but those who are interested can call main number and be put on a wating list.  Posted 3/25/2020, 3:46 PM, pg

Safe Parking Locations:
Ruggieri Senior Center
Brown Temple Church
Union City Apostolic Church
UC Kids Zone Family Resource Center
Our Lady of the Rosary
