Provides responsive assistance to low-income, limited English-speaking Southeast Asian communities, who are victims of crime. Works with law enforcement, private groups and individuals to fight crime and help victims overcome the consequences of crime and empower them to live safe and healthy lives.
application_process: Call for an appointment or visit during program hours.

description:
Notes: All in person meeting are closed. Services offered via online. Visit Trivalleyaa.org or aa.org for more information.

description:

The YFO (Youth and Familiy Opportunity Program) staff will be working from home answering calls and providing information and referrals. YFO/Laura DeRamos 510-589-4009 Work Cell.

Trains and supports parent support groups which meet monthly.

description:
Note: Visit https://www.acoe.org/mentalhealth for mental health related resources related to COVID 19. Update: 4-9-2020

name: Domestic Non-Violence Program
description:
Note: Office is open to the public. All Drug testing, domestic violence and DUI programs have been postponed until further notice. Group meetings are reduced to follow social distancing guidelines. Posted: 4-10-2020 4:13pm SMR

Course structured to educate participants on power and control in intimate relationships. Morning, evening and weekend classes available, classes vary by which are open for new enrollments.
application_process: Register in person

name: Domestic Violence Support
description:
Provides help for survivors of domestic violence and sexual assault. Types of abuses included are physical, emotional, psychological, sexual and economical. This also means any behaviors that:
  • frighten
  • intimidate
  • terrorize
  • manipulate
  • hurt
  • humiliate
  • blame
  • injure

Offers a women's support group for survivors of domestic violence.
application_process: Call for appointment and information.

name: Downtown Youth Clinic (DYC)-East Bay Adanaced Care
description: DYC is a safe place for teenagers and young adults (ages 13-24) to receive free testing and treatment for sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and HIV. The East Bay AIDS Center (EBAC) has a designated HIV youth clinic. HIV-positive youth can get the medical care and other support services. Testing is available by appointment. Testing and treatment are free, private and confidential with appropriate documentation.
application_process: By appointment.

name: East Bay Chapter Meetings
description:
Hold meetings every second Saturday morning of the month, except for July and August. Provides a room loop, captioning and a special sound system so everyone can hear, read and understand. For more information visit the State website at www.hearinglossca.org.  A chapter of the national Hearing Loss Association of America, The Nation's Voice For People With Hearing Loss. Visit www.hearingloss.org, or phone 301-657-2248. Chapter meetings provide the opportunity to:
  • meet others
  • learn about modern technology
  • how to cope and eventually to accept the loss
  • participate fully at the workplace and socially

description: East Bay Site Office supports families and individuals dealing with Alzheimer's disease and other forms of dementia. Serves Alameda, Solano and Contra Costa Counties. SUPPORT GROUP FOR CAREGIVERS meets at 12 locations in Alameda County. OTHER SUPPORT GROUPS INCLUDE: Early stage group meets in Lafayette. Interview required. For more information, call 925-284-7942. Spanish language support meets 1st wednesday of the month in Concord. For more information call Ernest Hidalgo at 408-372-9934. Group for dementia caregivers who identify as LGBTQ meets on 4th Wednesdays at Institute on Aging, 3575 Geary Blvd, San Francisco, 94118. For more information, call Erica J. Erney, LCSW, 408-530-6906 HELPLINE offers support, information and referrals 24 hours daily. Family Care Specialist, a trained counselor, does in-person and phone care consultations at no cost. Professional Education provides training for professional caregivers at residential care facilities. Family Education provides training for family caregivers.  SAFE RETURN PROGRAM is a nationwide support, registration and identification program for lost or found individuals with Alzheimer's Disease or related disorders. Initial enrollment fee is $55 for low-income individuals, Scholarships available.

name: Individual Counseling and Support Group
description:
Provides individual counseling and support group services for any victims or survivors of domestic violence. Support groups are held Tuesday and Thursday, 6:45-8:45; Friday, 9:15-11am.

NOTE:
In response to COVID-19, at this time, our Empowerment Center is closed. Our business lines (510) 574-2250 are still receiving calls and will be handling as much of our normal business as we can remotely. Anyone needing emergency support due to domestic violence should call our hotline (510)794-6055. This line is staffed 24/7 and will be operating as it normally does.

Our Safe House is currently full and we will continue to shelter the residents through this crisis and beyond. Posted 3/24/2020, 3:20 PM, pg

name: Safe Space Project
description: Provides support groups and services for vulnerable women and families living in the San Francisco Bay Area. Groups are confidential so that all participants feel welcomed and safe to share their experiences. Provides dinner and other support services, with groups generally lasting for two hours. Group discussions can be about (but are not limited to) domestic violence, homelessness, mental health, careers, family dynamics, parenting, and successes. Each week the topics can be steered by what participants are open to discussing in that particular session. Their facilitators do not provide answers or judge. Women are given the time and space to connect with one another, listen, learn, and find safety. Participants can come every week or when it is convenient with no obligation.
application_process: By phone or if interested in attending a support group, or for more information, please email safespaceproj@gmail.com.

Clients receive helpful tools, many benefits, and access to unlimited resources that can be used beyond their program. This program is open to groups of up to 25 people and runs every Tuesday, for 3 months with a month break between each cycle.

Call Center is staffed by registered nurses and registered respiratory therapists. Information is available by phone, e-mail or online chat with a counselor. Medi-Cal now offers up to 12 weeks of non-nicotine prescription medicine treatment. While behavioral modification support is still required for patients obtaining cessation aids, pharmacists no longer need verification of participation (i.e. certificate or letter). These enhanced benefits make access to treatment and counseling even easier. Ask your doctor about how these new benefits can help.

LOW FEE MENTAL HEALTH SUPPORT
Jonathan Julian is an AMFT serving the community through their practice at the Oakland LGBTQ Community Center. They are offering shorter term, low-fee therapy sessions between $30-$60 specifically for our LGBTQIA+ family who are struggling with their mental health during the Covid-19  pandemic. If you or a loved one needs extra support, you can find me on https://openpathcollective.org/ by searching my name. I specialize in expressive arts therapy and somatic mindfulness. Learn more about me at https://jjuliantherapy.com/

  • LGBTQ crisis intervention referrals

Offers a community center for lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer and questioning (LGBTQ) youth ages 11-23. Provides safe space for LGBTQ youth to explore their identities, socialize, build community, develop leadership skills, and receive non-stigmatizing, culturally competent mental health services. Our Space draws on best practice recommendations for working with LGBTQ youth to support the growth and progress of those they serve.

The Helpline is the gateway for Alameda County residents to get access and referrals to publicly-funded Substance Use Disorder screenings, assessments, and referrals to treatment. Screening and referrals are available in any language. The Helpline is available 24 hours a day. 7 days a week.
Clients needing SUD services will be screened, assessed and referred to the appropriate level of care (Detox, Residential, Recovery Residence, Outpatient, Intensive Outpatient, or Opioid Treatment Program. The screening takes approximately 15 Minutes. 
The Alameda County Substance Use Helpline is managed by Center Point, Inc Screenings can take place on the phone or in person at Center Point Fremont office.

description:
Note: Office is not open to the public. Not accepting new client. Posted: 4-17-2020 11:39am SMR 

Provides extended support in a clean, comfortable and nurturing recovery environment. Women share responsibilities while providing emotional support, love, and encouragement for each other. The goal is for each woman to leave with a recovery program plan. Plan should include: three 12-step meetings a week; getting a sponsor; writing a to do list (including keeping track of all appointments and phone calls); writing out a gratitude list every night before bed. House Curfew for everyone, every night is Monday-Thursday, 9pm; Friday-Saturday, 11pm; Sunday, 6pm. Curfew must not be broken. All rules are enforced.

Note: Office is not open to the public. Staff working remotely. Still doing intakes. Posted: 4-13-2020 11:29am SMR

A special program make available by the City of Fremont to support placement in one therapeutic community bed, until other resources can be found. Only one individual at a time for this special program.

eligibility: 18 years to 64. Resident of Fremont.

name: Highland Campus: Outpatient Substance Abuse Program
description: The Highland Hospital Substance Abuse Program is a comprehensive program serving substance abusers in Oakland and Alameda County. The program consists of two treatment modalities: Outpatient Drug Free Services and Day Care Habilitative Services. The Outpatient Drug Free Service is a group focused program and is available to all non perinatal participants. The Day Care Habilitative Service is available to pregnant women and women up to 60 days postpartum.  The six to nine month programs include: intake/assessment, medical evaluation, individual, group and family counseling. Other services include relapse prevention, parenting classes, sober recreation, acupuncture, urinalysis and child care. The program also provides case management services to parents substance abusers. Limited mental health services are also available to substance abusing clients in the program.
application_process: Enrollment by appointment.
required_documents: No Information has been provided by Agency.
eligibility: Resident of Alameda County.

name: Intensive Outpatient Program (IOP)
description:
Note: Not accepting new clients. Posted 4-14-2020 9:30am SMR 

Offers a psycho-educational program for chemically dependent adults. Designed to meet the needs of individuals that are active in daily living with things such as work, parenting, or school, but need ongoing support. This program includes the following: group therapy and education, individual counseling, family education and support group, relapse prevention, 12-step support and a free aftercare program.
application_process: Call Admissions office for confidential assessment.
required_documents: No Information has been provided by Agency.
eligibility: For adults age 18 or over with a chemical dependency problem.

name: Latino Family Services Center
description: Provides substance abuse treatment - outpatient programs for adult men, persons with co-occurring mental and substance abuse disorders, persons with HIV/AIDS. Gay and lesbian, seniors/older adults, men including criminal justice clients.

required_documents: No Information has been provided by Agency.

name: MAT - Medication Assisted Treatment Program
description:
Treats opioid addiction through the use of buprenorphine/naloxone films or tablets. Opioids include:
  • prescription pain killers (oxycodone, hydrocodone, codeine, morphine, fentanyl and others)
  • as well as heroin

**Only treats opioid addiction**
application_process: No waitlist, but must obtain medical clearance from primary care physician and complete an intake assessment with the program's behavioral health provider.
required_documents: None
eligibility: Adults 18 years and older who currently use opioids and want to stop using them.
schedule: Can call clinic during hours of operation but will need an appointment for the MAT program.

name: Men's Recovery Program
description:
Note: Now providing to-go meals from kitchen so that we may continue daily meal service to people in the most need in the community. Now shifted to a drive-thru approach for pre-bagged grocery pick-up process across our 13 mobile pantry sites. Residential programs continue to operate under shelter-in-place guidelines with everyone doing their part. Continue to operate overnight shelter within the public health guidelines that have been established.  

Offers long-term residential recovery program to men dealing with chemical dependency. Prior to graduation from program, clients are provided with an opportunity to reconcile with their families. Learning Center offers testing and program placement to address the educational needs of recovery program residents. Offers GED preparation and instruction in reading and basic skills.
application_process: Call or walk in to apply. Application is reviewed, then interview with Recovery Manager is necessary for acceptance into program.
required_documents: No Information has been provided by Agency.
eligibility: Man dealing with substance abuse and chemical dependency, willing to commit to Christian-based long-term program. Must go through interview with Recovery Program Manager.

Some of the staff from Cultura and Bienestar, is providing Mental Health Prevention and Support via Telephone, for those individuals that need to talk to somebody. Please refer them to us.
YFO/Laura DeRamos 510-589-4009 Work Cell.
C&B/Evelia Servin 510-331-2401 Work Cell.
Please feel free to refer families to us. We will try our best to give the right information and referral to the families.

name: Prison Counseling and Services; Residential Rehabilitation Program-Hayward
description: Provides a 1-year residential rehabilitation program based on Christian doctrine for former gang members and male drug abusers, age 18 or over. THE RIGHT STEP is a support group utilizing a 12-step approach for treating drug and alcohol abuse.  PRISON COUNSELING SERVICE provides counseling for inmates and placement in the Victory Home after release, if requested by the individual. Residents are required to attend all church meetings and share in the chores. Residents live under 24-hour supervision and may not be employed while in the program. Conducts Drug and Gang Prevention Crusades several times a year.
application_process: Apply by phone for information on availability and initial screening.
eligibility: Age 18 or over, adult males only.

name: Refugee Cash Assistance (RCA)
description:
Offers cash assistance for newly arrived refugees, newly granted asylees, certain Amerasians from Vietnam, victims of human trafficking, domestic violence that have or applied for a U or T visa. Cuban and Haitian Entrants are also allowed RCA benefits. Effective December 2007, a group of immigrants from Afghanistan and Iraq with Special Immigrant Visas (SIV) are granted the same benefits as refugees.

NOTE: Lobbies are Temporarily Closed to Help Prevent the Spread of COVID-19. The below Alameda County Social Services Agency office lobbies are currently closed. We will continue to provide essential services. Clients who are receiving or wish to apply for Medi-Cal, CalFresh, CalWORKs, Refugee Cash Assistance, and General Assistance may use available telephone, fax, mail, and online services. Applications, renewals, documents, and reports can be submitted for most programs online at www.MyBenefitsCalWIN.org. You may also submit information by fax at 510-670-5095 or by mail at P.O. Box 12941, Oakland, CA 94604.

During the temporary closure, limited in-person access will be available for the following:
  • Emergency Electronic Benefit Transfer (EBT) Card/ Benefits Identification Card (BIC) or check pick-up
  • Homeless mail pick-up
  • Cash Assistance Program for Immigrants (CAPI) Applications
  • Clients who do not have access to a telephone and need to comply with a required program interview
Applications will continue to be available at offices in designated areas for all benefit programs, and community members may complete, sign and return documents for processing using a secure drop box during regular business hours, 8:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Application Forms With Links

name: Western States Pension Assistance Project
description:

  • find pensions "lost" due to company mergers
  • re-locations or bankruptcy
  • submit claims for pension benefits
  • understand and interpret spouse or survivor benefits
  • deal with demands for re-coupment of overpayment

Can help with pensions sponsored by:
  • private companies
  • unions
  • local and state governments
  • railroads
  • the U.S. Government Services

name: AIDS Housing and Information Project (AHIP) - Public/Subsidized Housing Appeals Assistance
description:
Notes: No change to programs. Posted: 4-13-2020 3:29pm SMR

AHIP provides housing and social service referrals for people with HIV or AIDS. Maintains a database of AIDS-dedicated housing which is updated monthly. In addition, AHIP also has access to Eden I&R's database of low-income and market rate housing units that are not specifically for people with HIV. Program has a roving component whereby AHIP Staff take the database to various AIDS agencies throughout the county and work with clients in person. AHIP facilitates several housing workshops for case managers and clients throughout the county. Call AHIP for current schedule of roving sites, days, and hours.
application_process: Client intake by phone or in person, no application needed.
required_documents: No Information has been provided by Agency.
eligibility: Person with HIV/AIDS.

name: Complaints for Employment Discrimination, Public Accommodation and Hate Violence
description:
Investigates allegations of discrimination in employment because of:
  • race
  • color
  • religion
  • creed
  • ancestry
  • national origin
  • gender (including sexual harassment)
  • age (over 40)
  • marital status
  • pregnancy
  • family leave care
  • physical or mental disability
  • medical condition (related to cancer recovery only)
  • discrimination in public accommodations
  • complaints of hate violence

Only investigates actions which took place within the last 365 days in businesses which have five or more employees, or in businesses with one or more employees for harassment cases.
application_process: Visit the website or call to apply
required_documents: No information has been provided by Agency
eligibility: Open to all.

name: Equal Employment Opportunity Commission
description:
Investigates charges and enforces federal laws which prohibit employment discrimination based on
*race
*color
*religion
*sex
*national origin
*retaliation
*age
*genetic information
*disability.
Also enforces the Equal Pay Act.  Charges may be filed either in person or by mail. Charges for employment discrimination must be filed within 300 days of alleged discriminatory act.
application_process: Walk in services available Monday-Friday 8-4:30, Interviews Tuesday and Thursday, 8am-1pm. No appointment necessary, first come, first served. Allow 1 1/2 hours for interview. For more information, please check website at www.eeoc.gov. Please call first to ensure availability and obtain information on jurisdiction.
eligibility: Open to all.

The City of Fremont contracts with Fremont Fair Housing and Landlord/Tenant services. Provides information to tenants and landlords on rights and responsibilities.   • religion
  • sex
  • age
  • marital status

description:

  • color
  • religion
  • ancestry
  • national origin
  • sex
  • age
  • marital status
  • familial status

name: George E. McDonald Hall of Justice
description:
Note: Closed to the public. Limited staff is working on essential services. Response to emails and voicemails are taking a longer time to answer due to limited staff. Posted 4-13-2020 9:07am SMR
  • NOTE: Resumption of Court’s fax filing service for certain emergency-related Civil, Family, and Probate documents.
    o Expansion of documents that can be files at the Court’s drop box locations.
    o Drop box added for Probate documents at the Berkeley Courthouse.
  • NOTE: Order deems April 6 through May 1, 2020, to be holidays for most purposes o During COVID-19 crisis, all appearances in civil actions and misdemeanor appeals must be by telephone or video technology, and (b) all pleadings (except for initial service of process) and all court notices be served electronically
  • All jury trials will be continued, and jurors will not be called o Any prospective jurors who received a summons with a date from April 6, 2020, through May 1, 2020, are not required to report for jury service and will be considered to have satisfied their jury service
  • Effective March 30, 2020, Court SelfHelp Center available to assist customers Monday – Thursday from 9:00am – 12:00pm via the web using LiveChat.  LiveChat can be found on bottom of right corner of the Court’s  Self-Help Center web site  
  • Effective March 30, 2020, Court Self Help Center available to schedule one-on-one video appointments.  Customers will be identified during LiveChat or telephonic sessions and scheduled accordingly  Posted: 4/23/2020, 12:29 PM, ar
Through this courthouse, the Superior Court of California, County of Alameda, houses the Family Law Division and also the Self-Help Center. Court Clerk's Office hours: Monday-Friday, 8:30-2:30. Document drop box available to receive documents after 2:30pm. Building access is available Monday-Friday, 8-4. The Family Law Facilitator Center is located on the first floor. Hours are Wednesday, 8:30-12, 1-4 and Friday, 8:30-1. Family Law includes Dissolution, Separation, Nullity, Paternity, Domestic Violence and Civil Harassment.
application_process: By phone, walk-in.
required_documents: No information has been provided by Agency.
eligibility: Open to all.

Through this courthouse, the Superior Court of California, County of Alameda, houses the following Divisions for court customers: Family Law, Unlawful Detainers, Name Changes, Restraining, orders, Name Changes, Child Support, Small claims, Guardianships, Custody/Visitation, General Civil Action, Family Law Clinics-Spanish, Civil Harassment, Domestic Violence and Elder Abuse. They cannot provide legal advice and they do not represent either party. They are not able to provide assistance if you are already represented by an attorney. To hire an attorney, call the Alameda County Bar Association's Lawyer's Referral Service at (510) 302-2222. Please expect a wait time when visiting the center. Depending on the matter, you may be assisted on the day you arrive, you may be asked to return at 1:30pm for same day service, and/or you may be scheduled for one of our workshops. Given volume and staffing limitations, and so that we can provide full service to everyone who signs in, sign in may be closed earlier than posted closure time. They will be unable to assist anyone who arrives after sign in has been closed for the day. Court Clerk's Office hours: Monday-Friday, 8:30-2:30. Document drop box available to receive documents after 2:30pm. Building hours are Monday-Friday, 7:45-4, excluding holidays.
application_process: By phone, walk-in.
required_documents: No information has been provided by Agency.
eligibility: Open to all.

name: Volunteer Legal Services Corporation (VLSC)
description:
Note: During the COVID 19 pandemic, have re-structured services to be offered via a phone consultation and/or through a Zoom consultation. In person clinics have been suspended.

Provides free legal assistance to qualifying low-income persons in select areas of civil law in Alameda County. Offers two types of service: Clinics and Pro Bono Attorney Referrals (attorneys who won't charge a fee). Does not handle criminal matters. Does not assist those who wish to sue another party for monetary damages.

Clinics offer advice and assistance in the preparation of legal documents in the following areas:
  • Divorce/dissolution of marriage
  • General family law (custody, visitation, and spousal and child support)
  • Bankruptcy
  • Guardianship
  • Immigration/citizenship
  • Landlord eviction assistance (low-income individuals)
application_process: Call for assistance, participants must be scheduled to attend clinics.
required_documents: Dependent on a case by case basis.
eligibility: Low-income individual with civil legal problem; services for people at or below 75% median income of Alameda County.

name: Community Legal Assistance Saturday Program (CLASP)
description:
Note: During the COVID 19 pandemic, have re-structured services to be offered via a phone consultation and/or through a Zoom consultation. In person clinics have been suspended.

Offers a monthly, free, drop-in legal clinic open to the public.

Volunteer attorneys meet with individuals for 15-20 minute consultations. Attorneys are experienced in many areas of law including:
  • Family law
  • Immigration law
  • Housing
  • Consumer rights
  • Employment
  • Personal injury
  • Probate
  • and more
application_process: Visit during program hours.
required_documents: Bring any and all legal documents relevant to your questions/case.
eligibility: Open to all adults in Alameda County
schedule: First Saturday of the month at the Alameda County Law Library.

name: Root & Rebound Services
description:
NOTE:
Free Reentry Legal Hotline for advice only operates every Friday from 9:00 a.m.- 5:00 p.m. Pacific Time.  Our Hotline phone number is 510-279-4662 and it is free and open to anyone in California with a reentry-related legal issue, question, or concern, including those who are incarcerated. Can call collect.
If it is an emergency or urgent call 510-279-4662 Monday to Friday 9-5:00 PM.

Also offers FREE legal clinics for residents of Alameda County who have arrest or conviction records!  Check the website for a schedule of events or email staff in the Bay Area: https://www.rootandrebound.org/locations/california/
Appointments are highly recommended. We may not be able to accommodate calls that were not scheduled in advance.

If you have any questions or need help deciding if this clinic is right for you or If you have any questions, please call us at 510-279-4662 on Friday 9-5:00 PM or email Amber at adean@rootandrebound.org anytime.

Posted: 6/16/2020, 4:57 PM, pg

Offers legal support to those with records by providing a reentry legal hotline, community legal clinics and court representation. Through legal services, support is provided to help people navigate their rights to various needs like:
  • employment
  • occupational licensing
  • housing
  • record-cleaning
  • family reunification
  • parole/probation
  • obtaining an ID

Assist homeowners and tenants going through foreclosure and anti-eviction process. Provides them with loss mitigation assistance including helping them with loan modification process. name: Bureau of Consular Affairs - Travel.State.Gov
description: Website provides the information regarding International Travel for U.S. Citizens, Passports for U.S. Citizens, Visas for Foreign Citizens, and Intercountry Adoption and Abduction information regarding both U.S. and Foreign Children and Families.INTERNATIONAL TRAVEL: provides information on conditions abroad that may affect U.S. travelers' safety and security. Includes current country specific information, travel alerts, and travel warnings.OFFICE OF AMERICAN CITIZEN SERVICES AND CRISIS MANAGEMENT (ACS) works with overseas embassies and consulates to provide emergency services to Americans abroad. Can help to send money overseas to assist U.S. citizens, repatriate the remains of loved ones who have died, assist victims of crime, help U.S. citizens who are detained in foreign prisons, and administer a repatriation loan to bring home destitute Americans. Operates a 24-hour Duty Office Program.PASSPORTS: provides information on how to apply, how to renew, how to report and/or replace a lost or stolen passport in the U.S. (for overseas help, contact the nearest U.S. Embassy or Consulate), how to correct or change U.S. passport information, and updated information on new requirements.VISA is required for foreign citizens to travel to the U.S. Type of visa depends on purpose of travel. Visa Services, Public Inquiries Division provides a selection of pre-recorded information and the ability to talk to a visa specialist during business hours.OFFICE OF CHILDREN'S ISSUES provides assistance to parents who seek to adopt orphans from abroad (intercountry adoption), and handles international parental child abduction (the abduction of a child from one parent to another country by the other parent).
application_process: By phone, online or e-mail for information.
eligibility: Open to all.

description:

Those that cannot make the Thursday general immigration clinic, or prefer to have a one-on-one consultation with an attorney, can make an appointment for an in-depth one-hour consultation by calling. The consultation fee is $60.  Assists with Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) and Deferred Action for Parental Accountability (DAPA).

At the clinic, reputable deportation defense attorneys gather at the Oakland Office to provide individual consultations. The Deportation Defense consultation fee is $30.

Note: Office is closed to the public but still assisting clients. Call and leave a message for further assistance. Posted: 4-29-2020 11:21am SMR 

Assists with a variety of immigration issues, including: political asylum, U visas (for victims of crime), deportation defense, DACA (Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals), DAPA (Deferred Action for Parental Accountability), VAWA (Violence Against Women Act, for victims of domestic violence who are not US citizens), NACARA (Nicaraguan Adjustment and Central American Relief Act), complex naturalization, immigration effects of criminal convictions, and benefits eligibility. Also represents detained clients.  Clients are asked to leave voice message. Messages are picked up and returned twice a week.

name: Information and Services
description:
NOTE: USCIS will neither consider testing, treatment, nor preventative care (including vaccines, if a vaccine becomes available) related to COVID-19 as part of a public charge inadmissibility determination, nor as related to the public benefit condition applicable to certain nonimmigrants seeking an extension of stay or change of status, even if such treatment is provided or paid for by one or more public benefits, as defined in the rule (e.g. federally funded Medicaid). Posted 4/17/2020, 12:41 PM, pg

Provides information on immigration benefits online and by phone. Immigration benefits which the USCIS oversees are:
*citizenship
*lawful permanent residency
*family and employment-related immigration
*employment authorization
*inter-country adoptions
*asylum
*refugee status
*replacement immigration documents
*foreign student authorization. Website includes form instructions, processing times for applications and case status. Clients can also register to get automatic e-mail updates as requests are processed.

description:

Professional attorneys, staff, law school students and pro-bono attorneys offer legal counseling and services for low-income immigrants and refugees. They charge low fees for legal services. All inquiries and consultations are confidential.  Legal services include, but are not limited to: Family Based Petitions; U-Visas for Crime Victims, VAWA; Consular Processing; Waivers; TPS; Naturalization; Deferred Action and Work Permit for DREAMers.

Please call us for more information later in the month of March to determine when our clinics will resume.
Thank you for your understanding.
Stay well.

name: US Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS); DACA (Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals) DAPA (Deferred Action for Parents of Americans and Lawful Permanent Residents)
description: The Secretary of Homeland Security announced, starting February 18th 2015, that certain people that came to the United States as children and meet several key guidelines may request consideration of deferred action for a period of 3 years, subject to renewal, and would then be eligible for work authorization.Individuals that can demonstrate through verifiable documentation that guidelines are met, will be considered for deferred action. Determinations will be made on a case-by-case basis. Visit www.dhs.gov/deferred-action-childhood-arrivals or www.uscis.gov/childhoodarrivals for more information.
application_process: Call or visit website for complete information.
eligibility: Must meet eligibility criteria; visit web site for complete information about DACA and DAPA programs.

name: Housing Assistance Center
description:
Note: Office is closed to the public. Staff is working remotely and checking voicemails periodically. Call for more information. Posted 4-14-2020 11:22am SMR 

The City of Oaklands Housing Assistance Center offers a one-stop approach for obtaining housing services and resource referrals by Oakland residents, homeowners, and property owners and managers. 
HOUSING ASSISTANCE RESOURCES:  A trained Housing Intake Specialist supports clients in:
  • finding and securing safe and affordable housing
  • Connects clients with City, County, nonprofit, private, and other public housing related resources
  • Provides referrals for tenants and landlords 
A Community Housing Advocate helps Center clients navigate access to housing services. Serves as an advocate in obtaining those services. Assists clients in accessing resources for rent, deposits, home repairs and other housing needs. Works with County and City specialists to alleviate complex housing needs. 
STREAMLINED ACCESS TO CITY HOUSING SERVICES, INCLUDING: 
  • Tenant petitions and landlord/tenant mediation for rent increases and related adjustment issues
  • Low-or no-interest loans and grants for residential rehabilitation, home repairs and energy retrofits
  • Foreclosure prevention and mitigation assistance for homeowners
  • includes housing counseling and referrals for legal services
  • Information about first-time homebuyers assistance and workshops
NOTE: The Housing Resource Center is temporarily closed due to the Covid-19 health crisis. If you'd like assistance from a Housing Resource Center staff person at this time, please send your email to either: Guadalupe Pacheco at gpacheco@oaklandca.gov or Azaria Bailey at ABailey-Curry@oaklandca.gov . Thank you very much.

description:
Note: Office is closed to the public. Staff is working remotely and checking voicemails periodically. Call for more information. Posted 4-14-2020 11:22am SMR 

Enforces the Rent Adjustment Ordinance which prevents excessive residential rent increases. If a landlord increases rent by more than the allowable annual rent increase in less than a 12-month period, or gives more than one increase in a 12-month period, tenants may file a petition with the Rent Adjustment Program. Provides a hearing process and mediation to ensure that rent disputes are resolved in a fair and equitable manner.  Tenants can file petition due to decreased housing services, which can include serious Code violation.
application_process: Call for information.
required_documents: No information has been provided by Agency
eligibility: Residential units covered under the rent ordinance in the city of Oakland.

name: Rent Review Ordinance (RRO)
description:
Note: Office is closed to the public. Development Services is suspending most services for all divisions, but staff will be available by phone or email to provide assistance and answer questions. Posted: 4-29-2020 4:08pm SMR 

The Rent Review Ordinance applies to all residential housing units (apartments, condominiums, and single-family homes). Provides renters and landlords an outlet to resolve rent increase disputes through:

  • mediation
  • a hearing before the Rent Review Board (if increase is over 5%).
Must call or email within 15 days following a rent increase notice for services.

eligibility: Open to all.

name: Rent Stabilization Board
description:
Rent Board Staff provides information and counseling to landlords and tenants. Services provided include:
  • Calculate and certifies individual rent ceilings
  • conducts administrative hearings and issues decisions on landlord and tenant rent adjustment petitions
  • collects registration fees
  • maintains a database of registered rental units
Owners of rental property covered by the Ordinance are required to register units with the Board . Must file a registration statement and paying annual registration fees, which cover the program's cost. Each residential rental unit in Berkeley is subject to the Rent Stabilization Ordinance unless it falls within one of the enumerated exceptions. Also provides mediation for landlords / tenants regarding tenancy issues.

Also offers free information resources regarding tenant and landlord rights and responsibilities relating to the ordinance.

name: Eviction Moratirorium for the City of Hayward
description:
Note: Hayward City Council voted to expand this moratorium to September 30, 2020. For information about Housing and the Residential Rent Stabilization Program please check our website at www.hayward-ca.gov/housing. Rent Review Kiosk: Hard copies of the Residential Rent Stabilization forms and materials are available for self-service on the first floor of City Hall. File a Petitions: Petition can be filed by mail, sent by email to housing@hayward-ca.gov, or dropped off at the Rent Review Kiosk drop box. File Notices: Rent increase notices and notices of termination of tenancy can be filed by mail, emailed to rentalnotifications@hayward-ca.gov or dropped off at the Rent Review Kiosk. Pay Rent Stabilization Fee: Rent Stabilization Fee can be paid by mail or online at https://haywardselfservice.us/hss/ Mailing Address: Housing Division 777 B Street, Fourth floor Hayward, Ca 94541 To view a list of departments with modified hours or services visit our website: www.hayward-ca.gov/covid-19. For your convenience, please see below for frequently asked questions and services.   COVID-19 Updates Make a Payment   Hayward Water Support   Pay a Traffic Ticket   Report an Abandoned Vehicle  Signup for AC Alert Subscribe to Public Safety emails   For all other questions or concerns, please utilize our Access Hayward system. Updated: 7-13-2020 9:58 am SMR. 

Provides a one-time rent relief grant directly to landlords on behalf of low-income tenants to reduce burden on tenants due to COVID. Helps offset corresponding lost revenue that landlords need to provide housing services. Ensure landlords receive the revenue needed to maintain housing services. Bay Area Community Services (BACS) will be administering the program on behalf of the City of Hayward.
application_process: Must complete online-application: https://housing.bayareacs.org/
required_documents:
Valid ID (any photo identification including name, date of birth, etc.)
Current lease agreement or documentation of rent paid
Documentation of income and income loss (such as paycheck stubs showing difference in amounts; application or screenshot to Unemployment Department; two bank statements showing difference, Layoff Letter, etc.)
Proof of housing crisis (such as documentation certifying tenant is behind on payments, unable to pay rent, etc.). If the tenant does not have this, they will need to certify/attest they have a bona fide housing crisis and/or do not have the ability to pay the next months’ rent.
W9 from Landlord / Property Owner (BACS can provide a copy of the form). Tenants must request a copy of the W-9 from their landlords. Landlords may submit to the tenants or to BACS directly.
eligibility:
Applicant must be:
o Very low-income tenants (up to 50% AMI) OR
o Low income (up to 80% AMI) with high rent burden (30% or higher).
• Have been unable to pay full rent because they experienced and can demonstrate hardship resulting from COVID-19 in one or more of the following ways (with flexibility regarding other experiences not listed):
o Loss of or reduction in employment or wages
o Increased medica

name: Eviction Moratorium County of Alameda
description:
On Tuesday March 24, 2020 the Alameda County ​Board of Supervisors unanimously ​passed an emergency ordinancesuspending evictions in the Unincorporated County for renters and homeowners ​who are experiencing loss of income, significant out-of-pocket medical expenses or childcare needs as a result of the County COVID-19 shelter mandate.  The Ordinance took effect immediately upon passage and will be in effect until April 23, 2020 ​unless extended by the Board. 
Unincorporated County residents who are served a Notice of Termination ​while the ordinance is in effect ​will need to provide documentation of loss of income, substantial medical expenses or child care impacts.
Violators are subject to a $1000 fine per violation and may be subject to civil proceedings. 
​The ordinance and associated staff report are available here.
application_process: Visit website for more information http://www.acgov.org/board/bos_calendar/documents/DocsAgendaReg_03_24_20/GENERAL%20ADMINISTRATION/Regular%20Calendar/CDA_293014.pdf
required_documents: No information has been provided by Agency
eligibility: Residents of the Unincorporated County for renters and homeowners ​who are experiencing loss of income, significant out-of-pocket medical expenses or childcare needs as a result of the County COVID-19 shelter mandate.

name: Eviction moratorium for residential renters, nonprofit organization renters, and small business renters of Oakland
description:
Note: On Tuesday, May 19, 2020, the Oakland City Council extended the eviction moratorium for residential renters, nonprofit organization renters, and small business renters (generally those with fewer than 100 employees) through August 31, 2020. Updated: 7-13-2020 9:07 a.m. SMR 

This moratorium will prohibit most evictions, effective immediately and continuing through August 31, 2020, unless the City Council extends that date. Additionally, the moratorium prohibits residential rent increases above 3.5% (the Consumer Price Index, or CPI) and prohibits any late fees related to COVID-19 issues in residential units. Unpaid rent will still be due, and the moratorium does not relieve tenants of the obligation to pay unpaid back rent in the future. The Ordinance also prohibits evictions based on nonpayment of rent that became due during the Local Emergency when the tenant suffered a substantial reduction of income or substantial increase of expenses due to COVID-19.
application_process: Visit the website to apply
required_documents: No information has been provided by Agency
eligibility: Oakland residential renters, nonprofit organization renters, and small business renters (generally those with fewer than 100 employees).
schedule: Online hours 24/7. No information has been provided by Agency for phone hours

name: Eviction Moratorium- Union City
description: The eviction moratorium will last until May 31, or until the expiration of local or state emergency declarations, whichever is later. It will protect any residential or commercial tenant from being evicted for not paying their rent “where the failure to pay rent is from income loss resulting from the coronavirus.
application_process: Tenants have 10 days after rent is due to notify landlord
required_documents: Any documents showing loss of income or any kind of medical documentation
eligibility: Renters in Union City will need to notify their landlords within 10 days after their next rent payment is due that they won’t be able to pay because of a coronavirus-related issue.

name: Navigating Emergency Tenant Protections and Resources for Renters during COVID Pandemic
description: A number of temporary measures to protect tenants during the public health emergency have been enacted at state, county, and city levels.
application_process: Call to apply
required_documents:
Tell your landlord in writing as soon as possible, before rent is due. Keep copies of what you send and your landlord’s responses.
Take pictures of all documentation that shows you lost income because of COVID-19. These can include:
Paystubs
Notes from your boss
Bank statements
Notices that your kids’ school is closed
Doctor’s note showing that you had to stay home to care for yourself or someone else
eligibility: Must be a resident of the Bay Area

name: Alameda County Workforce Development Board (ACWDB)
description:
COVID-19 Emergency Response Suppotive Services (CERSS)
Alameda County Workforce Development Board (ACWDB) has launched a new initiative to help some of our most vulnerable residents receive up to $800. Eligible participants can receive additional resources to help offset the cost of housing, transportation, utility bills, and technology to facilitate working from home.
 
These services are in addition to unemployment benefits and other safety net programs. ACWDB has four locations geographically disbursed throughout Alameda County. Interested individuals should contact their nearest Career Services Provider immediately as assistance is limited and available on a first-come, first-served basis.
Provides job seekers with access to tools, resources and services that assist them with obtaining their employment goals. These services are available throughout Alameda County through a Comprehensive One Stop Career Center (serving the Eden area in Hayward) and through workforce services networks that serve the Tri-Cities, North Cities, and Valley areas of Alameda County.

Offers RAPID RESPONSE services to Employers and Dislocated Workers when companies undergo downsizing, relocation, layoffs and closures. Provides information on: career planning, vocational retraining, and re-employment.
application_process: By phone or online for program information. No direct services offered at WDB's administrative offices.
required_documents: Verification of eligibility for federal programs.
eligibility: Residents of Alameda County excluding the City of Oakland or job seekers who have worked in Alameda County excluding Oakland during 6 months prior to application. The unemployed, underemployed, low income, or individuals with barriers to employment. Laid-off workers eligible for unemployment benefits.

description: Offers employment, housing, vocational training, treatment services to individuals returning from custody or on probation, or pre-trial. Provides assistance in removing barriers and meeting court-ordered requirements.
application_process: Call for an appointment or visit during program hours
required_documents: Depending upon the service, documentation may be required for identification, proof of income, employment status, etc
eligibility: Open to individuals returning from custody or on probation

name: The Lord Provides Resource Center
description: Assist the residents of the West Oakland community. Strives to place local people into local jobs and housing units by referrals. Is a self-help and one-stop career service center that offers a full staff, a computer lab, career counseling classes, tutoring, resume writing, counseling, case management, and job and housing search assistance.
application_process: Walk in.
eligibility: Low income, homeless.

name: Tri-Cities One-Stop Career Center (Serving Fremont, Newark & Union City)
description:
Notes: Office is closed to the public. Staff is working remotely to assist clients. Assistance provided via online. Posted: 4-14-2020 11:30am SMR

Offers resources to the general public for the purpose of seeking jobs, training, or education. Resources specifically for job seekers and more focused support for special populations in the community. Also offers business resources and services specifically for employers. There is no charge for any of our services. Provides access to the California Employment Development Department's (EDD's) online CalJOBS program and access to filing for Unemployment Insurance on-line or call 800-300-5616.
application_process: Walk-in or register online; bring photo ID and social security card.
eligibility: Legally authorized to work. Additional requirements may apply.

name: Tri-Valley One-Stop Career Center
description:
Notes: Office is closed to the public. Staff is working remotely to assist clients. Assistance provided via online. Posted: 4-14-2020 11:30am SMR

A publicly-funded resource for jobs, employment, education, training, and business development in the Pleasanton, Dublin, and Tri-Valley communities. For more information about services and programs, a weekly orientation is held every week (by appointment only). Services offered include job search workshops with instruction in job seeking, resume writing and interviewing skills. Offers weekly job clubs and networking opportunities, vocational, career and supportive counseling as well as classroom and on-the-job training. Resources include: job listings, library of career-related materials, job search videos, information on vocational schools and training, community resources, labor market, and employers. Access to the California Employment Development Department's (EDD's) CalJOBS program. Offers basic beginning computer assistance. Provides computer stations with word processing, database, spreadsheet, internet resumes and career resource software as well as fax machines, copiers and phones for employer contact. Also assists employers in finding employees by posting job opportunities.
application_process: Walk-in to register; bring photo ID and social security card; CalWORKs clients schedule an appointment.
eligibility: Legally authorized to work. Additional requirements may apply.

name: Youth Employment Opportunity Program (YEOP)
description:
Provides special services to youth age 15-25. Assists youth in achieving their educational and vocational goals. Services include:
  • peer advising
  • referrals to supportive services
  • workshops
  • job referrals
  • placement assistance
  • referrals to training and community outreach centers
application_process: Visit during program hours
required_documents: No information has been provided by Agency
eligibility: Youth, age 15-25 at risk of not achieving educational or occupational goal.

name: Academic Advising and Career Education Center (AACE)
description:
One-stop center for both academic advising and career development assistance, and career services. Counselors guide students in understanding and completing all General Education and graduation requirements in addition to helping them clarify and attain their career goals. Services include:
  • Career Education
  • Major Exploration
  • Academic Advising
  • Resources for employers, students with disabilities,etc.
application_process: Call for an appointment
required_documents: No information provided by Agency
eligibility: Students attending the University

name: ACBHCS Vocational Program
description:
Note: Due to many pharmacies being currently shuttered, and in case of the event of a prescribing emergency the pharmacy team and the Office of the Medical Director is available to assist in identifying alternate resources.  Please call 510-567-8106.

Note: Office is not open to the public. Call for more information. 
Posted 4-10-2020 3:19pm SMR

Provides Individual Placement and Support, Supported Employment to mental health consumers that have expressed an interest to work. Consumers are referred from Service Teams representing mental health clinics in Alameda County Behavioral Health Care Services (ACBHCS). Job Plans are based on the individual preferences of the consumer and include vocational counseling and outreach, competitive job search and retention, and ongoing collaboration with individuals team.
application_process: Must be referred by case manager, a Service Team or Level 1 Specialty provider. If not currently receiving these services can call ACCESS at 1-800-491-9099 to assess service needs.
required_documents: No Information has been provided by Agency.
eligibility: Must be a part of a mental health service team at Alameda County Behavioral Health Care Services and be at least 16 years old and able to express an interest and motivation to work.

name: CalFresh Employment and Training Program (CalFresh E&T)
description:
Prepares Clients for possible employment through a variety of activities, including job club and job search. Employable General Assistance and/or CalFresh recipients are currently not required to participate in employment program for continued eligibility.
NOTE: Lobbies are Temporarily Closed to Help Prevent the Spread of COVID-19. The below Alameda County Social Services Agency office lobbies are currently closed. We will continue to provide essential services. Clients who are receiving or wish to apply for Medi-Cal, CalFresh, CalWORKs, Refugee Cash Assistance, and General Assistance may use available telephone, fax, mail, and online services. Applications, renewals, documents, and reports can be submitted for most programs online at www.MyBenefitsCalWIN.org. You may also submit information by fax at 510-670-5095 or by mail at P.O. Box 12941, Oakland, CA 94604.

During the temporary closure, limited in-person access will be available for the following:
  • Emergency Electronic Benefit Transfer (EBT) Card/ Benefits Identification Card (BIC) or check pick-up
  • Homeless mail pick-up
  • Cash Assistance Program for Immigrants (CAPI) Applications
  • Clients who do not have access to a telephone and need to comply with a required program interview
Applications will continue to be available at offices in designated areas for all benefit programs, and community members may complete, sign and return documents for processing using a secure drop box during regular business hours, 8:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Application Forms With Links

required_documents: No Information has been provided by Agency.

name: California State School for the Deaf Supportive Services
description:
Program provides:
  • infant education
  • preschool education
  • elementary education
  • secondary and high school education
  • career and technical education
Continuing and community education is provided through local schools and adult education programs. The school is also a residential program and a resource center providing information and referral for the northern California area. Students from nearby communities attend on a day school-basis.
application_process: Referrals through local school districts and parent application.
required_documents: No information has been provided by Agency
eligibility: Age birth to 21, must be diagnosed deaf or hard of hearing.

name: CalWORKs Program (LaneyWORKs)
description: Teaches, trains, counsels and helps CalWORKs students to facilitate transition from public assistance to employment and self-sufficiency. Provides case management, academic, career and personal counseling,  job readiness training and child care. Also offers referral assistance for financial aid, assistance with books and supplies, work-study and internships, and job search/placement assistance.
application_process: By phone, in person.
eligibility: Students on TANF or CalWORKs.

name: Career Advancement Programs; Pathways for Men and Women
description:
Note: Office is closed until shelter in place has been lifted. Still able to leave messages for staff. Posted: 4-16-2020 12:22pm SMR

Offers professional skills development, such as communication, goal-setting, and a network of support to help individuals create new opportunities for themselves, their families and their communities. Helps individuals work with each other and with top career coaches. They develop specific action plans for job retention and career advancement. PATHWAYS is a 6-session workshops designed to help participants learn what it takes to excel on the job. Includes conflict resolution, problem solving, teamwork and communication skills. Applications are accepted on a rolling basis. Workshops meet once a week for 2 hours, for 6 weeks.
application_process: By phone (EXT 213) to request an application. For Pathways program: Applications accepted on a rolling basis.
eligibility: Low-income men and women working, ready to determine next steps in career. Not appropriate for individuals in "active job search" mode.

name: Career Connect
description: Career Connect is a 7-week career exploration and preparation program for Oakland students Grades 6th-12th. Students will get a jump start on their career planning as they begin or continue to sharpen their skills through interactive learning activities. Exploration of career fields will broaden students’ knowledge while narrowing their career and college choices as they assess their skills, talents, and interests. Career and life skills will be built upon simultaneously.
application_process: Call for information
eligibility: Oakland tudents in grades 6-12

Note: Currently offering program called Access technology resources for UC Berkeley students in need of technology resources. Can apply to access free laptops and WiFi while supplies last. Devices will be mailed to students who are unable to pick them up on campus.

Take an online self-assessment test
Complete a two-week prerequisite online course
Commit to 8-10 hours per week to study and complete coursework
Ashland, Cherryland, San Lorenzo, Union City, Newark or Fremont resident

Individuals 19 years of age or older
Ashland, Cherryland, San Lorenzo, Union City, Newark or Fremont resident

name: Champion Workforce (Employment)
description:
Note: Closed until further notice. Posted 4-10-2020 2:10pm SMR 

Assists homeless and extremely low-income adults to enter the workforce. The program is designed to systematically help participants address barriers to obtaining employment and receive training in key areas to develop workforce skills. After undergoing training, men and women are placed in temporary labor positions in painting, maintenance work, security and customer service.
application_process: Apply by phone.
required_documents: No Information has been provided by Agency.
eligibility: Homeless and extremely low-income adults.

name: Civicorps Corpsmember Academy
description: Offers a charter high school serving young adults 18-26 years old. Reinforces students' basic academic skills. Teaches students tools and techniques for academic success. Through active research, students also develop a leadership agenda and improvement plan for communities. Students supplement field work by attending evening and Friday classes. Graduates earn a high school diploma.
application_process: Visit the website or call to apply
required_documents: Photo ID, Social Security Card
eligibility: Youth (ages 18-26)

name: Community Employment Services Program
description:
Note: Following the ‘Shelter-in-Place’ guidelines and all programs have been suspended till May 31st.  Programs are scheduled to resume in June, but this is all subject to change.  Staff will be reaching out through letters, telephone calls and updated website information.  This is to protect the residents of Alameda County from contracting COVID-19. Posted: 5-4-2020 9:27am SMR 

Provides job search, placement and training, as well as travel training for adults with intellectual and developmental disabilities. Assists in developing employment opportunities with businesses in the community, and matches individuals eager to work with those employers. Provides ongoing job coaching and support at no cost to the individual or company. Provides support such as mobility training to ensure the person can get to the work site, individualized job coaching, education about benefits and responsibilities of SSI/SSA recipients, and referral to independent living skills programs.
application_process: By phone when referred by case manager from RCEB (Regional Center of East Bay, La Familia, or Asian Community Mental Health Services). Must complete application and screening process.
required_documents: Referral required from Regional Center
eligibility: Adults over the age of 22, a resident of Alameda County, a client of the Regional Center of the East Bay, and primary diagnosis of an Intellectual and/or Developmental Disability (program entrance criteria available).

name: Downtown Streets Team
description: Homeless and at-risk Team members 18 and up, beautify Hayward through their work experience program. In return for their volunteer services, they recieve a basic needs stipend and access to Case management and employment services. An individual can get connected with DST by coming to their Weekly Success Meeting, every Tuesday. It is located at the Hayward Area Historical Society, located at 22380 Foothill Blvd, Hayward, CA 94541. The meeting is at 12:30 pm and typically lasts around an hour.
application_process: Walk in.
eligibility: 18 yrs old or older. Come to Tuesday Meeting and get on the waitlist.
schedule: These hours are open for anyone to join their Weekly Success Meeting. This is the entry point of Downtown Streets Team. The program runs throughout the week once someone joins the Team.

name: Education and Support Services
description:
Provides peer support, mentoring, support for textbooks, and school enrollment assistance. Also offers referrals to on-campus support for formerly incarcerated college students. Other support services include:
  • Transportation
  • Referrals to supportive services agencies
  • Financial literacy
  • One-on-one intensive case management
  • Barrier removal to help meet educational goals
  • Referrals to vocational training 
  • High School Completion (Diploma, GED, HiSET)
  • Transition to college and financial aid supports
  • Career training education 
  • English as a second language (ESL)
  • Adult basic education 
  • Academic Counseling
application_process: Visit during program hours
required_documents: No information has been provided by Agency
eligibility:
Must be over the age of 17 and not be a high school graduate.

For First Place for Youth: Must be between the ages of 18 and 24

BOSS: Mon 1pm-3pm, Wed 1pm-4pm

Rubicon Programs: Mon & Thu 1pm-4am, Tue 9am-noon 
Youth UpRising: Tue & Thu noon-7pm

name: Employment Programs
description: CAF operates a Work Activity Program (WAP). In collaboration with the Regional Center of East Bay and the California Department of Rehabilitation. The Work Activity Program is CARF (Commission on Accreditation of Rehabilitation Facilities) accredited. WAP has been providing individuals with vocational skills and paid work experience. This business division is called Custom Assembly and Packaging (CAP). CAP operates an on-site Assembly and Packaging business at CAF Richmond facility. Working with Custom Assembly and Packaging, individuals enrolled in the WAP program are employed by CAP. Provide packaging, labeling and assembly services for a variety of businesses that have contracted with CAP. Participants earn an income and are provided resources. Enables them to secure more mainstream employment. To augment the participants vocational training and developing employment skills, individuals are provided on-site adult education classes.
application_process: Call for intake
required_documents: No information has been provided by Agency
eligibility: Must be receiving services from the Regional Center of East Bay.

name: Environmental Training Center
description: A youth employment program for youth age 16-24. Youth learn job and life skills through their participation and work on various crews. Services are coordinated with Counseling Center; group counseling sessions are required. Options include: URBAN GARDENING: Youth learn organic farming techniques, sustainable agriculture, and sales and marketing while creating a beautiful area within the community. Youth maintain a produce garden.
application_process: Apply by phone.
required_documents: No information has been provided by Agency.
eligibility: Youth, age 16-24

name: Food Service Training - Berkeley
description: Offers training that focuses on basic culinary, barista and customer service skills for jobs in cafs, restaurants and other food retail businesses. In addition, there is a strong job readiness component that includes resume writing, job search, interviewing, and other skills needed to transition into the food industry. TRAINEE REQUIREMENTS: Must love to cook and bake, be 18 years of age and older, low income, eligible to work in the U.S. or is in the process of getting a work permit, committed to finding a job in the food industry upon graduation, physically able to complete training, for example work on feet for 8 hours a day and lift 25 pounds, drug and alcohol free, free of violent or weapon-related offenses, able to read recipes in English, willing to receive follow-up calls from program staff after graduation. For application information call their training hotline and have a pen and paper 888-283-3522 or email at info@breadproject.org.
application_process: Call 888-283-3522 for application information.
eligibility: See "Trainee Requirements" in Program Description for details.

name: Foster Youth Job Readiness and Employment Referrals
description: Offers employment specialists to assist current and former foster youth and probation youth with all aspects of their job readiness and employment search. Staff helps youth explore vocational interests and options, locate job readiness resources and pursue employment opportunities.
application_process: Walk-in, apply by phone, referred by social worker.
required_documents: None
eligibility: Current and former foster youth and probation youth, age 16-24.

name: Goodwill Academy
description: The Goodwill Academy is a vocational education program tailored to help those with very little work experience. The Program focuses on four major areas: work skills, career development, life skills, and support services. Provides hands-on work skills training at 28 stores and three plants, which enables participants to receive a paycheck while attending program. While attending this training, participants attend Goodwill Academy classes and receive individualized job and career services.
application_process: Visit during program hours. Referral necessary from Social Services Agency for GA.
eligibility: Resident of Alameda County, Contra Costa County or Solano County.

name: Kitchen of Champions Culinary Program
description:
Note: Closed until further notice. Posted 4-10-2020 2:10pm SMR 

Offers a hands-on culinary employment training program. The program helps prepare people for fair-wage positions in the food and hospitality industry. Provides classroom and hands-on training, workforce readiness basics, case management and job placement. Students in the training program get real-world practice, working under a master chef and helping prepare the meals served at the Dining Room.
application_process: Apply by phone.
required_documents: No Information has been provided by Agency.
eligibility: Homeless and extremely low-income adults in Alameda County.

name: Laney College (CalWORKs, Child Care, Health Services, Project Bridge)
description:
Note: Campus Is Closed Until Further Notice. Remote services are now available. Posted: 4-28-2020 4:06pm SMR 

Accredited California community college offers academic education, academic and career counseling, and other support services for diverse students of all ages. Offers associate degrees, certificate programs, career and technical education, and courses transferable to 4-year colleges and universities.  ADMISSIONS & RECORDS: Contact 510-464-3121, Monday-Friday, 8-4:30 or go to Room A109.  CalWORKs PROGRAM: Offers vocational and educational training programs that lead to self-sufficiency. Provides case management, resource referrals, financial aid assistance, employment services, and childcare assistance. Contact 510-986-6946 for more information.  CHILD CARE: Provides free, limited child-care services for pre-school children of qualified full-time students. For more information, contact 510-464-3574.  HEALTH SERVICES offers TB skin testing, stress management, first aid, health checks, weight checks, nutrition counseling, health insurance information, flu immunizations, and family planning. For additional information and appointments call 510-464-3516.  PROJECT BRIDGE provides programs for adults who want to strengthen basic skills in reading, writing, math, computer, and study skills. Contact 510-464-3411 for more information.  FINANCIAL AID INFORMATION: Contact 510-464-3414, e-mail inquiry to laneyfinaid@peralta.edu or go to www.peralta.edu.
application_process: By phone, in person, or online.
eligibility: Age 18 or older, or under age 18 with GED or high school diploma.
schedule: Chancellor; Friday (only drop or pick up any paper); call for hours during peak registration.

name: Las Positas College CalWORKs Program
description:
Note: Campus is closed to the public. Available online. Posted: 5-1-2020 10:33am SMR 

The Las Positas College CalWORKs program serves CalWORKs students and their families. Provides educational and career opportunities. Offers an array of support services that enable CalWORKs students to:
  • complete their educational goals
  • find meaningful employment
  • transition into the workforce
application_process: Visit during office hours or visit the website or call for more information
required_documents: No information has been provided by Agency
eligibility: Must be a current CalWORKs participant with their local County Welfare Department and must be interested in enrolling, in the process of enrolling or currently enrolled in classes at LPC

description:
Offers adult educational services such as:
  • GED courses 
  • ESL Family Literacy Program
  • ESL citizenship classes
  • ESL college and career readiness courses
  • Pre-apprenticeship math courses
application_process: Call or visit website for class application information. Some classes require orientation and assessment.

name: Oakland Women's Center Supportive Services
description: Women's Centers International manages the Oakland Women's Center. Provides free training workshops in four core areas: Business Management and job skills, Adult Education( Literacy, ESL, GED), Health Education for women and response to sexual and domestic violence. They provide referrals for housing and any service that we do not yet directly provide. The center is a safe environment that fosters a cross-cultural sisterhood of support for low-income women who want to build more prosperous lives.
application_process: Visit during program hours or call to apply
eligibility: Must be female.

name: Opportunity Build
description: A pre-apprenticeship training program that prepares unemployed and under-employed adults with barriers to employment for entry-level jobs in the construction, energy efficiency and solar industries and for union apprenticeships. GETS provides classroom and hands-on training / technical training. During the 9 to 11 weeks of training, participants learn basic construction skills, earn OSHA 10 and First Aid/CPR certifications, strengthen applied math skills and work on employment readiness. During and after classroom training, participants receive 12 months of case management and job placement support from GETS staff who help in identifying and securing employment and union apprenticeship opportunities.
application_process: Phone, walk in, by appointment or referral.
required_documents: No information has been provided by agency
eligibility: must be 18 or older with HS Diploma/GED, Valid I.D and Social Security card.

name: Police Explorer Program
description:
Offers leadership programs to prepare students to be active in the community, learn more about law enforcement career, obtain valuable work experience, and take on more responsibility as a young adult. Basic volunteering includes:
  • Ride-Alongs
  • Traffic Control
  • Evidence Searches and more
application_process: Call Officer Iain Fry to apply.
required_documents: Proof of age and school transcripts.
eligibility:
-Must be between ages 14-19
-Must be enrolled in high school and maintain a 2.00-grade point average or higher OR
-Possess a high school diploma or GED with qualifying scores
-Must demonstrate a good level of responsibility and maturity

name: Refugee Employment Services
description:
Provides refugees with job search skills, employment counseling, job development, and job placement to help them effectively integrate into American life. Also assists with job retention. Vocational ESL provided at Oakland office. Services also provided in Spanish at Oakland office.

March 11, 2020

Dear Members of our Community:
As the news of the coronavirus (COVID-19) continues to evolve, we at Catholic Charities East Bay are making efforts to protect the health of our staff and of our community.
We are therefore cancelling all walk-in consultation and housing clinics through the end of March.
Individual appointments and other business operations will continue, unless additional advisories suggest limiting in-person activity.
 
Please call us for more information later in the month of March to determine when our clinics will resume.
Thank you for your understanding.
Stay well.
application_process: Walk in, apply by phone.
required_documents: No Information has been provided by Agency.
eligibility: Refugees, asylum seekers and immigrants.

name: School for the Blind
description: Offers an on-campus vocational and job skills program, as well as an apartment living program for older students. A comprehensive on-campus assessment program is provided to students who attend public schools (by referral only). A transition program is available to students age 14 or over.
application_process: Joint referral from parent and school district.
required_documents: No information has been provided by Agency
eligibility: Age 5-22, visually impaired, California resident.
